posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528589
Factories work towards an average, small shops work to the individual qualities.

In a factory they just say each part is such and such dimension and call it good, this results in most instrument falling into an acceptable range for the quality they are targeting with a certain number of each batch going to the extremes of either complete garbage or amazing. In the small shop they try and get the most out of each bit of wood, the best possible instrument for the given materials and the luthiers skill, the dimensions of any given part of the instrument will be worked to a mechanical property instead of a physical dimension. So for a soundboard they will have a range of stiffness and weight which they will work towards and not care if it ends up thicker than expected as long as at it falls into that range for stiffness and weight.

Essentially it means the small shop is more consistent, they have few if any instruments which go to those extremes and when they do get such an instrument it is priced accordingly instead of being priced at its model's price.
>>2528613
Ease of playing is generally a setup issue. Unless you buy direct from the maker and that maker sets up the instrument for you then it will need to be setup when initially bought to suit your style. Playability is a personal thing and a balancing act, higher action increases dynamic range, you can pluck the string harder without it hitting the fret board, but it also means it is harder to fret. If you are playing a piece which requires a large dynamic range than a low action may make it easier to fret but more difficult to achieve that dynamic range.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528602
>The big difference is how easy it is to play.

(Disclaimer: I don't actually "play" any string instrument yet.)

I don't really believe this. Musical instruments, in general, are very subjective. Worse, a lot of them (and violins might be the worst here) seem to be subject to this weird elitist attitude. I'm pretty sure the playability (in the most basic sense) is going to be much more dictated by specific design decisions than overall "quality".

Case in point: I bought literally the cheapest viola I could find on eBay. It was under $40, including shipping, bow, case, and some dirty rosin. I got it mostly as a comparison to an experimental instrument I was/am working on. It's perfectly playable. It doesn't sound all that great, even ignoring my poor playing, but it's not difficult to get a solid note out of. There are things that could be slightly better on that front, but nothing that should really affect price. For example, the notches on the nut were way too shallow, the bridge was set too high, and the fine tuners were garbage. All fixable for little or no cost, but I didn't exactly expect much for $40 to begin with, so whatever. From what little I've seen, issues like this generally don't exist in even lower-end stuff (my sister's violin didn't have problems like this, and was under $200).

To the specific point that >>2528613 was asking (factory vs "handmade"), there should be literally no difference. There isn't, fundamentally, any difference between a factory and a "workshop". If you're doing production work in a workshop, the difference between the two is nebulous and vague in the first place. Regardless of whether you have something being assembled by a line of 20 people or one guy in a leather apron, the only thing that's going to make a difference (and this applies to literally everything ever made) is whether or not the one(s) making the instrument give a shit about the end product or are only in it for the paycheck.

>>2528668
Yes, and the reason is that before circa WWII steel was an art more than a science and as a result there was wild variance in quality which means you needed to compensate for potentially poor edge retention for planes primarily used in heavy production work. With modern steels like A2, PM-V11 or Shiro-/Aogami #1/2 you can keep an absurdly sharp edge for a full day of work AND these planes aren't being used on production lines but for specialty pieces and by hobbyists.
If you want to do production flattening with hand tools then the most important compensatory feature isn't a chip breaker but a corrugated sole for the dramatic reduction in friction meaning you don't have to keep waxing the plane. For someone who makes few pieces of bespoke furniture it's not exactly a problem to run the blade over a strop twice a day or running a block of paraffin down the sole every now and again.
Different times, different design considerations.

>>2528561
Those are both pretty basic reactions/procedures. I think I did both of those in my first year as well. Chemistry is a very complicated subject and lab techniques can get quite advanced. Typically chemistry courses have a theory and lab component that run simultaneously, so you apply whatever it is you are currently learning. Those two examples would be something done in an intro to organic chemistry course. Upper year courses you can deal with things like more advanced purification, air sensitive reactions (Schlenk line, glove box, etc), pyrophorics, many types of spectroscopy (UV VIS, NMR, IR, etc), chiral specificity, etc. There are a lot of branches to cover, though there is quite a bit of crossover between lab techniques

Caffeine extraction is a basic lab technique/concept (liquid liquid extraction based on solvency, and purification through recrystallization) and gets you using basic glassware (separatory funnel, flasks,maybe a rotovap, hotplate, scale). Nylon is a cool looking but simple demo showing polymerization. You literally just put two liquids in a beaker then pull some tongs through it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
you can ghettoize some things but there are others you will need, otherwise you can only get so far. You need ventilation, either by fume hood, backyard, etc. You need a hotplate to control precise temperatures for reactions as well as a means to accurate observe the temp. You need glassware, obviously. You need solvents, for organic/inorganic separations. You definitely need a digital scale (the more accurate the better, but you can get by with chink/aliexpress type pocket/food scales). You need utensils like stirrers, small powder spoons, etc. You need de-ionized water (distilled water in most stores). You definitely need graduated cylinders to measure fluid volumes.

you can get clever and get pretty far, but you can only get so far before you need very expensive machines to analyze the structure of and verify the identity of compounds.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2527930
>Honestly chemistry isn’t that dangerous
I mean...it's not, but the problem is that it can easily go into dangerous territory if you're not careful and if you don't know what you're doing.
>>2528560
>with regard to the dangers, is it not enough to just study well the exact synthesis i want to perform?
No, because if you only study that one synthesis, you don't know what other synthesis might be taking place if, due to lack of knowledge, or due to contaminants in the reactants, or due to some other imperfection, it goes sideways somewhere along the way. For example, you might, say, use the wrong vessel for performing the experiment, and have the reactant react with the vessel too. Or you might not be able to keep the reaction at the required temperature (maybe it's exothermic, and you poured too much, which sped up the reaction significantly, or some random contaminant acts as a catalyst, etc), and thus have it turn into something else while it's outside of the correct temperature range. What then?
Not to mention that things are never perfect. You will never only work with analytical grade reactants, perfectly clean glassware, perfectly linear heating and have perfectly fitted seals. There will always be a degree of uncertainty and imperfection which will eventually sway the reaction in a different direction. And if you don't have the theoretical base and the experience needed to anticipate the direction in which that reaction will be swayed, and therefore correct it before it happens, it can and will go very badly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528132
>The biggest problem is autistic faggots assuming that one or two drive configurations can and should cover every possible combination of other factors

But there SHOULD only be a few. Ignoring security fasteners (which are homogay to begin with), there really should only be like four, max:

Spline has the highest torque capacity of any internal drive, but requires tight tolerances in order to work properly. If it slips, it's ruined.

Hex/torx are almost as good as spline, but is slightly more forgiving on tolerance.

Robertson/square is, again, slightly less capable than hex/torx, while being more usable in the case of fastener corrosion or damage.

Slotted is objectively fucking terrible, and should never be used. Its only saving grace is that you can easily turn all of the other really shitty fasteners into slotted, obviating the need for special drivers that you will never use again.


The rest should not exist, don't @ me. If you've got some niche scenario in which you "need" some other kind of screw, it's probably because you made some shitty other design decision. Fix THAT instead of making a new meme drive type.

>>2518885
It was the combination of a few factors, but the biggest one is called "dot gain". Colors are made by mixing size and location of dots in 4 different colors. Sort of like how digital screens mix RGB pixels together to create colors.

When you print those dots, there are factors that can make the dots larger or smaller than intended. In this case the paper it was printed on absorbed the ink more, creating larger dots. There might have been other factors, I don't know.

The ad was already very dark and moody looking to begin with. I did one quick pre-press at a local printer, and it came out dark... I had them lighten it a bit and due to time/money had to send the files right away.

I was really proud of the ad. It was my first "big" print ad, and I also handled the photography and design from top to bottom. Like, I was planning on framing a copy of it lol.

My water went out. What do?

A year or so ago it went out a few times, and each time I just had to switch the reset lever on my well pressure tank. That always fixed it, but sometimes it would happen again soon after. When it happened a few times in a day, I figured it might be a bad breaker so I replaced the breaker and had no more issues until today, a year or so later.

Flipping the switch on the pressure tank that always fixed it in the past is not fixing it this time. My breaker seems fine from what I can tell, and I did flip my breaker off and on a few times.
When I press the reset lever on my pressure tank with the plastic cover off so I can see what is going on, I will sometimes see a little spark at some of the contacts when they make contact or release. Does this mean my breaker is definitely good, or could the spark be caused by some static electricity or something?
And only the contacts on the right seem to spark (at the spot I circled in purple). The left ones (circled in green) do not spark. And even the right ones don't spark every time.

I also heard that the contacts can get some sort of "carbon build-up" on the surfaces that can cause issues, is this correct and if so what is the solution? Sanding them?
What other potential problems could cause this? Do I need to replace the whole pressure switch , and if so, what do I need to look for to make sure I am getting the right thing?
Is my breaker a possible cause or is the sparking indicative that the breaker is fine?

Thanks

is 1C generally the best rate to charge lipos? I've seen some spec sheets that say they can charge 2-3C.
I've been pumping 6A into 6x450mah packs, nothing gets warm, but wondering if i'm ruining the longevity of these small ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: >>2527385

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527464
1C is like going the speed limit. Best to stick to it whenever convenient, but not a big problem to break it by even 3x when in a hurry.

I charge at 1C at home and at 2-3C in the field. You DO shorten the lifespan, but it's a trade I'm willing to make. Also, my lipos die a horrible firey death before they get chemically exhausted from charging a bit too fast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527464
1C is only necessary to max the life of the battery, or if you probably/possibly have bad cells. Otherwise the manufacturer recommended charging rate should be fine.

That bondo stuff with loose fibers won't work, you need to wrap woven fiber around the fingers and then paint on resin, build it up in layers. posts.com: What are some absolutely essential tools/tool kits for a new homeowner starting fresh?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524206
Also a relative newfag here (at least when it comes to house stuff), I've found it helpful to just buy things as you need them Because it depends what you're trying to do.
At the very least, get yourself:
>A step ladder
>A longer ladder
>A screwdriver (or set)
>A hammer
>A tape measure
>A spirit level
>Some pliers
You can now assemble furniture and hang paintings. Depending on your garden situation you might also want some basic tools for that.

One thing I'll say is that you probably don't need a drill yet and can get by with an impact driver. Also, Ryobi is great for our application. You probably don't need anything fancier.

Also, Youtube is great. The Canadian boomer at Home RenoVision DIY is a decent starting point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524206
People vastly overestimate how many tools they need as a "homeowner" especially starting out.
Youll soon realize that the cliche of shit breaking all the time just isnt true (unless you bought an actual dilapidated house)
If something breaks, you arent going to be able to "fix" it without going to the hardware store anyways.
Buy the tools you need as you are buying the replacement stuff.

Bare minimum
Multi Bit Screwdriver + Adjustable Wrench + Slipjoint Pliers will do 90% of the random "fixes" (aka tighten something thats loose) in the house.

Tape measure and spirit level.

posts.com:
>>2527235
Lots of kids end up in humanities literally just because math and science are so poorly taught in high school. By the time they are in high school, most kids dislike math and science because they think they're too hard. They aren't hard, they've just been failed in one or more topics. Failing is a normal part of learning any subject, but schools don't give kids time to go back and retry things they didn't master the first time. So kids just accept that they "don't know" x subject and have to leave it at that because it's time to move on. Teachers have curriculum goals that they have to meet so that when standardized testing rolls around, enough kids can give enough right answers to keep the school funded.

Subjects like language arts and history are a lot harder to fail, because there's less to get wrong, so kids end up thinking these subjects are the only things they are "good" at. These subjects are often tested with essays read by human proctors, which are way more forgiving than multiple choice math and science.

When it comes time to graduate high school, theres enormous pressure on kids to go to college and pick a major. They, logically, want to pick a major they are likely to succeed at, so using their limited window into education and job training, they arrive at the conclusion that they have to take humanities.

In an ideal world, kids would learn hard subjects at their own pace, and take as much time to master subjects as they need. For many reasons this is extremely impractical for a system that needs to educate thousands of kids per county, but that's the result you get: kids who just think STEM isnt for them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528062
All three are viable options but how much to do depends on other stuff we can't see like the de site of the wood and how you intend to fasten the parts together and attach the remaining load carrying parts...but in general-

>make the wood thinner
Where and how much is ok depends on the loads on it and in what direction, and how the parts are joined...too thin and glue joints don't have enough area and screws split things and dont have enough meat to grab.
A lot of light wood structures are lashed together for this reason, a d because the flex in those joints prevents cracking and splittting.
>cut away some material
As long as you aren't taking away material that needs to be there it's a good option, and this gs like rounding off edges let you leave lots of meat at the joints for strength. Not a lot of weight loss for the effort but it all adds up.

>or make holes
Most significant way to get big weight loss, but also high risk of adding fatal weak points, especially in solid lumber. Keep the size under 1/3 of the parts width is a basic rule, and consider loads and potential pressure points when locating them.
For exame on a cross piece that has a bending load applied to the ends, one hole in the middle creates a weak point with a solid lever on either side but four holes spread out equally allow the entire piece to flex more uniformly...as long as both remain within the load limits, the one with more holes is less likely to snap in two, and less total weight means less of the load is the structure.
>I'm thinking that the holes would be the worst because they cut the fibers of the wood and make them much shorter, is it a valid concern ?

That's not how wood fibers and wood strength work, the biggest issue is that solid wood is susceptible to splitting with the grain; holes can make this more likely either from loading or just natural wood movement, especially if the location is wrong. That's why wooden structures that need to be ultralight use plywood.

If you’re going to make holes, use a forstener bit to make sure they are perfectly round and if possible, glue a short piece aluminium or pvc tube inside that matches the hole size. This keeps it a lot stronger and allows for more holes without risking fatigue cracks.

>>2528371
There is no universal "for or against" them that applies in every case, they are simply one option for adjusting the balance between strength and weight considerations in structural members. It should go without saying that caution is warranted any time you might weaken a structure, but it's equally important to consider that removing unecessary weight can actually improve the load bearing capabilities of structures and make them less susceptible to catastrophic collapse under certain conditions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2497894
I've been down this road before. Don't do it. Electrical stuff is the absolute worst to try to keep organized, since every type of thing (resistors, caps, connectors, fuses, relays, ICs, sensors, LEDs, the list goes on) has 100 different subtypes, and often each one of those subtypes has a subsubtype. When you start putting shit in tackle boxes, unless you're very careful about how you organize it, you might as well throw it away, because you're never going to see it again.

I've found the best way to avoid clutter and minimize "forgotten items" is to maximize literal visibility of your stuff. Genuinely, taking the doors off of a bunch of my floor-to-ceiling storage cabinets was one of the smartest things I've ever done. Those harbor freight small parts organizers can be a blessing and a curse. If you're going to use one, you need to label each drawer, otherwise it just becomes a garbage container, and you might as well throw it away.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2497889
you're gonna want a multi-layer approach for top hoarding. First you line the walls with peg-board. Then at chest level you're gonna want work-bench tier table/shelving that goes along the sides of the work room. You can then subdivide the lower sections into actual drawers or cubby hole spaces for large containers or tool chests. Now since you didnt finish the cieling you're gonna wanna get some cordage and hang stuff off of it, like baskets full of gloves and shit. We arent done yet, because that ladder in the corner can be used to access the rafters, where you are going to shove all the shit you will never use but dont want to throw away up there. Get some 2x6s and make some light shelves that fit between the rafters. Dont put anything heavy up there though, because realistically the framing of your roof isnt designed to hold weight in that direction but its fine if its just a few hundred pounds. probably.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For many people and projects, they are a poor source of lumber.
However, they are not useless.

The GOOD - They are often free for the taking and they are often hardwoods

The BAD –
Their size limits their usefulness.
They are often aged or damaged.
They are more awkward to haul home than a stack of boards.
They require disassembly.
They do not all use the same sized boards, you have to find matching pallets to get a bunch of boards that are all the same dimensions.
They sometimes are treated with Methyl Bromide, which is a health risk.
They have nail holes, often quite noticeable.
Sometimes they have unknown substances spilled on them from leaks.
It is a hassle to make them not look like pallet wood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallets are stamped, but not on every board.
Only some pallets have risky chemicals, many are plain wood.

Pallets stamped HT are heat treated and safe to burn.
Pallets marked MB contain Methyl Bromide and should NOT be burned.

>Methyl bromide is a fumigant used to control pests in agriculture and shipping. Methyl bromide also depletes the ozone layer. Therefore, along with other countries, the United States has phased out production and consumption of methyl bromide with important exceptions for critical uses as well as quarantine and pre-shipment.
https://www.epa.gov/ods-phaseout/methyl-bromide

Is there a safe way to get these carcinogens out/off of the wood? Not to my knowledge.

Easy rule of thumb if they are MB or you don’t know for sure.

Don't Burn Them!
Keep the sawdust out of your lungs and off of your skin. This applies to all sawdust, actually.
Don't make cutting boards or other things that touch food.
Paint will seal them if you are still worried about excessive contact.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: burn them and just die sooner you poorfag junkie fuck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Using pallets intact has some applications, especially if you can find them the same size. I have seen furniture, animal pens. and greenhouses made from them. (The furniture is usually pretty ugly.)

MB-treated boards make decent outdoor planter boxes and other rustic things like shelves for your shipping container shed to store imitation crab meat.

Taking it apart isn't hard if you have the right tools.

If you are going to salvage a whole bunch of pallets, consider getting a specialized prybar. I would prefer to get one locally, so I could try it out to see if it is worthwhile, then be able to return it easily if it is crap.
https://www.1001pallets.com/top-7-best-pallet-buster-pallet-breaker-reviews/

https://www.99pallets.com/pallet-projects/diy-storage-shed-from-pallets/

This is unlikely to become a Sticky, so please help it stay on the board by posting pics of your projects and links to pallet idea websites that might inspire others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882
Induction doesn't require material to be magnetic, just conductive. Energy transfer is more efficient when magnetic, but steel will become non-magnetic when sufficiently heated. If anything you would prefer a non-magnetic, non conductive crucible such that the metal is directly heated rather than indirectly through walls of crucible. Big challenge in getting up to temperature is all of the heat losses due to radiation and convection. For cast iron / cast steel graphite-based crucibles are most commonly used. Not straight graphite but don't know the exact formulation.

Oh, it's you. You need to learn thermodynamics. The steel furnaces are lined with ceramic liners (usually some cementatious clay). This + the steel's ability to be cooled by air is enough to avoid melting.

Whe the clay liner fails you get all the molten metal shooting out the hole in the now-melted steel.

The lid and liner are very thick relqtovely speaking; this insulates the melt inside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2488793
Most of the iridium on Earth (probably) ended up bonded to iron and is still molten beneath the crust, which is the reason there is so little accessible to us.
We do mine it, it does occur naturally, it's just rare stuff.
There's more of it in meteorites than in the layers of Earth we have access to, that's not unusual, that's true of numerous elements.
This makes it useful as one of the indicators of large meteorite impacts, one of many valid and observed indicators.
That's about it. It's useful stuff, been produced and used commercially for just shy of 200 years now.
It's just uncommon in the top layers of the Earth's crust where we can access it.

In the scale of the universe, it's an element with a fairly high atomic number (77), so it's going to be relatively uncommon compared to "most" elements with lower atomic numbers. This isn't a perfect rule, but it's a decent rule of thumb.
The reasons why are complex, you'd be wanting to read up on cosmic nucleosynthesis to get an idea of how various elements were formed by the Big Bang, exploding stars, merging stars, cosmic rays, all kinds of neat stuff. Isotopes and stability play a big role in this, certain elements don't have known stable isotopes, and are so "unlikely" to exist in nature they may well not exist anywhere in the universe they aren't actively being produced by an intelligence with the intention of producing them, like we do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2490205

The most viable iridium deposits on Earth are massive, fuck-off huge ancient impact craters from around the time the crust was forming an stabilizing. those are actually a big part of the reason Africa has so much mineral wealth in general. Outside of that, you find a some in old volcanic complexes that have eroded away.

You can pull "native" iridium from copper and platinum refining in minuscule amounts, or in very rare igneous deposits as microscopic bare nuggets alloyed with other metals. There's a couple iron-iridium minerals and one copper-iridium mineral that forms naturally as inclusions in deposits of other platinum and iron-group minerals, but they're vanishingly small - 5 - 10 micron in diameter, and very very sparse.

Basically, the tiny amount that we currently produce is all produced "accidentally" as a byproduct of refining other rare metals. most of the viable sources occur as a "side product" of mining gold conglomerates in Africa and gold sands in North America.

it's a damn shame, as iridium complexes might end up being some of the most compelling phosphors and catalysts ever discovered, but no one in their right mind is ever going to suggest large scale industrialization of an iridium-based chemistry. Even metallurgical uses are basically all luxury items at this point, with some very low volume extreme-condition industrial uses.

The power requirements are MASSIVE. Always used for small batch metallurgy or low melting temp metals that need VERY carefully controlled temperature profiles. Large batch Induction heaters are almost always used as reheaters or preheaters these days. Arc heating or gas fired is still preferred.

Induction smelters are great for fine control and quick batching but are more expensive than any other heat source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2499296
Heat red hot. Oil quench with pliers no swishing (firing tip down). Heat at AT LEAST 500°F (more like 600 if you can) until it shows a good darkening yellow color.

That should give you a proper hardened profile with enough tempering to not explode.

Google search (O1 tool steel tempering graph) and aim for 50-55HRC if you want more info.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508422
Easy recipe: take some generic 1020 or 4140 or something (a proper quenchable tool steel if you are brave) and cut it into small chunks (or buy some steel shot if lazy). Take some cast iron powder. Pack the chunks VERY WELL and tightly into a crucible and seal it or at least borax the shit out of the top. Bring to half way between the melting temperature of the cast iron and of the steel.

The cast iron melts and diffuses into the steel. Eventually the chemistry of the steel and castiron average out until it is a mass of solid chunks and intermingled semi-solid mushy not-quite-cast iron. Consistency of a concrete that is a little too dry. You need to only heat it long enough to get this diffusion about half way - if it becomes 100% solid you went too long. Allow this to slowly cool so that everything diffuses well together but maintains a distinct pattern.

The steel you used is mostly the original steel (now higher carbon) but is all bound with a web of very carbidic pearlite, carbides, and other high-Si intermetallics.

>>2513066
Anything that is carbide forming (tool steels, bearing steels) resists carbon diffusion through martensite (huge Ni/Cr atoms + small Mn/V atoms fug up the diffusion) so you can develop a decorative oxide layer but maintain strength and hardness.

Look for "impact grade" tool steels if you're making a sword.

>>2516112
Acid reacts with and rapidly corrodes the surface of metal. Can be used in combination with a resist to make some sort of pattern or just applied generally to expose virgin metal, as for weld testing.
You can get both sulfuric and hydrochloric acid from a well stocked hardware store. Sulfuric is sold as drain cleaner, and HCL is sold for cleaning concrete and masonry labeled as muriatic acid. Even the acetic acid in cleaning vinegar will work, albeit more slowly. Copper sulfate, which is sold for horticulture and aquaculture can also be used for etching, but I'm not sure of the specifics of the process.

>>2518598
With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. I found a 3D printing filament "Mold-Lay" that is low temp enough to be melted out in the kitchen oven, but still makes a smoky mess and more expensive than PLA. I usually use 50% sand 50% plaster. The 45 minute plaster works better than the 15 minute plaster (and is cheaper too). Use a paint brush to paint the mixture on the surface before fully submerging to make sure it fills all the nooks and crannies. Using 356 aluminum rather than potluck aluminum will give much better results (found someone on Ebay selling for $3/lb).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521382
Instead of just putting a model in plaster and burning it out you make a multi-layered shell of porous ceramic glaze and essentially sand. You then can preheat the entire mold after burnout and fill with metal then let slow cool in the furnace.

The finer the model (wax is historically used for ease of burn out, modern SLA works great but takes longer to burn) the better the end product.

>>2522066
I think some of the defects I am getting are related to formation of steel during melting out the PLA either due to excessive water or incomplete curing. Molds will often show cracks and the solution is wrap them in duck tape so they don't fall apart due to incidental contact, though I've never had a cracked one break. Perhaps I would be well served by a low temperature curing step. I'll also try using less water next time and mixing water in as needed. (1 plaster : 1 sand : 1 water was too much so I mixed more plaster and sand in; next time I'll start with 1 plaster : 1 sand : 0.5 water). Though maybe something a little richer in water for the first coat on the casting only to make sure it sticks well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
Not sure if it's any use but I have a bit of experience. You shouldn't be seeing blue with just the fuel on, you also don't have to make a huge acetylene flame before lighting the oxy, I'd say once the flame has volume and is putting out thick black smoke then you're good for the oxy. When you're tuning the flame people talk about a neutral flame but it's kinda hard for a beginner to grasp what that means, basically you watch the little flame needle (or needles depending on your nozzle) sticking out the hole (or holes) in the nozzle tip, you want that needle to be as long as possible without the flame flickering or changing color, the base of the flame should be blue with the yellow and orange further out, if you try to make the needles too long the flame will become a bright white and jet out of the nozzle in a sort of thin beam so that's a good way to tell you that you went too far. Sometimes gauges are weird so I can't really help you there, used to have a gauge at the shop that would correctly read the oxygen psi at the pressures we needed but the needle would never drop below 20 psi even when we turned it off. Make sure you have a welding/brazing tip and use good filler, keep the filler shielded by the outer flame not the the inner needle and don't dip that needle into the puddle, that's pretty much it for mild steel, it's kinda like tig when you start going.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
>>inb4 don't weld with it

Whoever told you that was a moron. The little torches are great for sheet metal and light work. OA was the only way to weld aircraft parts before TIG was invented in WWII.

Get a copy of the Oxwelders Handbook, no later than 1939 which was peak OA welding era. They're about ten bucks online.

This forum is one of the last with quality OA welding and related equipment posts. It's noob friendly. https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/2-MIG-TIG-Stick-And-Oxy-Fuel-Welding/

Blacksmithanons will also enjoy this place: https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/121-Sticky-Forum

A shade 5 face shield is most comfy. Goggles are shit. Your local welding supply has them. Sunglasses also work well but I wear glasses and prefer shields which protect the face.

Determine what make/model torch you have. I buy tips via Ebay and only use US-made torches. Torches are typically cheap and I've got several from the 1930s I pressure tested (with clean compressed air) that sealed perfectly. Ivory soap is fine leak detector and recommended in old factory literature.

Don't sweat the gauge so long as you don't run too high a psi which for OA welding there is no need anyway.

PSI info and some background:
https://forum.millerwelds.com/forum/welding-discussions/7731-pressure-regulator-setting-for-o-a-cutting-and-welding

>>2525741
Generally you can look at the pH.
Mild Akalines for organic stuff like food stains and microbes.
Mild Acids for inorganic stuff like limescale, rust, all the oxides. But you need to rinse/neutralize those surfaces after because microbes thrive in mildly acidic environments.
Strong Akalines aka Bleach kinda works on both.
Strong Acids are too destructive for regular household cleaning, imo.

The fancy OTS cleaners have surfactants mixed in that makes scrubbing far easier so don't dismiss them completely.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2526545
Yes. Jacks aren’t made to hold cars up. They’re made to lift cars and then you use the jack stands to actually hold the car. Any jack is going to slowly lose pressure and drop, and a well used jack is going to drop faster. The Chinese steel teeth on a $30 pair of jack stands are far more reliable than the Chinese rubber seals inside the jack.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2526554
Layer it bra. Long johns on real cold days, decent pants, good socks, and then your choice of undershirt, a hoodie or fleece (the hoodie hoods are always more comfy than big jackets), and then whatever jacket that isn’t too puffy and thick.

You gotta strike that balance right before you start to sweat. 25F with the sun and manual labor, you will be good in the hoodie. 0F with wind and clouds just standing around, get your top layer jacket. Something about shells, the swooshy sounding jackets like windbreakers that don’t suck up water, those are good for top layers.

Look for gloves with thinsulate if that’s still around. I used to love these mittens where the 4 finger cover flips up and you get those hobo looking gloves and can use your fingertips.

>>2518032
Depends on the task, but apparently I am an odd one given the replies so far, but I like ratcheting screwdriver with bits. But it is hard to find a good one, honestly still looking the good one broke after several years and the new versions aren't as good. Lots of them now have hollow handles for storage, but that really weakens it as the handle bends and sometimes even breaks in my hand when I grip too hard, the old metal ones never did that. Reason I still like them is I have had projects where I drive in hundreds and hundreds of screws by hand. I had bits wear out which lead to other problems. By switch to fresh bits as I go I didn't have to keep buying screw drivers which cost more then a box of bits. It also lets me change to other types as the job had 8 screw types, so finding a comfy handle each item was annoying. Lastly the ratcheting helped for some oddly positioned screws, but you want fine gear teeth so you don't waste a lot of the rotation.

I also have regular screwdrivers as well for the more detail work as they aren't loose.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524503
It would be dumb to pretend that no VOCs present health/ environmental hazards (not that anyone's done that) but it's equally dumb to lump any and all VOCs together as health/environmental hazards or to pretend that restrictions on them and off-gassing levels are based on the hazards of direct exposure-

"...the regulations that we have promulgated for VOCs in architectural coatings and consumer products are in place only because many VOCs photochemically react in the atmosphere to produce ozone, a component of smog."

To be clear, that doesn't mean direct exposure is "safe"-

"some chemicals that are toxic are exempt from the VOC regulations because they are not considered to be photochemically reactive. Therefore, some products that are labeled as "no VOC" or "low VOC" under the CAA can actually contain volatile organic chemicals that are toxic, sometimes at high levels.

In addition, the concept of lowering "total VOC" (TVOC) does not always assure safer products because the individual VOCs that make up TVOC can vary widely in their toxicity. While it is probably prudent to use products with lower VOC levels, it does not assure that the products are any better (and they may even be worse) than products with higher VOC levels."

Point is that "VOC" and "offgassing" get tossed around like they're always a direct threat, but lumber, houseplants, many foods like fruit and humans offgas VOCs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525686
if its closed no water vapor ever reaches the cold metal
u value calculator says 0,001L water condenses inside the foam every winter (almost nothing) and the same will evaporate during summer, (that's for living rooms a shop has less moisture anyways)

open cell PU foam will look different you get 0,180L (6 ounces of water) every winter and only 4,3 ounces will evaporate during summer, eg. the foam will become wet.

calculations were done for 10F 90% moisture outside winter/ 68F 50% moisture inside.

does anyone know a english side to calcualte r-value and dew point? i always use ubakus or the old version
the modern side which can be switched to English but its not perfect, for some materials you need to register.

posts.sub: I made code that takes screenshots of 4chan threads
posts.com:
This code uses the pyautogui library to take a screenshot of the 4chan thread, and the google-auth and googleapiclient libraries to authenticate with and upload the file to Google Drive.

To use this code, you will need to install these libraries and also have a Google account with the Drive API enabled. You will also need to provide the URL of the 4chan thread you want to screenshot in the thread_url variable.

PYTHON CODE STARTS HERE:

import requests
import shutil
import pyautogui
import google.auth
from googleapiclient.discovery import build
from googleapiclient.errors import HttpError

def screenshot_thread(thread_url):
# Take a screenshot of the 4chan thread
pyautogui.screenshot(thread_url + ".png")

def upload_to_drive(file_path, file_name):
# Set up the Drive API client
SCOPES = ['https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive']
creds = google.auth.credentials.Credentials.from_authorized_user_info(info=None, scopes=SCOPES)
service = build('drive', 'v3', credentials=creds)

# Create a new file in Google Drive
file_metadata = {'name': file_name}
media = MediaFileUpload(file_path, mimetype='image/png')
file = service.files().create(body=file_metadata, media_body=media, fields='id').execute()
print(f'File ID: {file.get("id")}')

def main():
# Replace this with the URL of the 4chan thread you want to screenshot
thread_url = "https://boards.4chan.org/g/thread/7777777"

# Take a screenshot of the thread
screenshot_thread(thread_url)

# Upload the screenshot to Google Drive
file_path = thread_url + ".png"
file_name = "4chan Thread Screenshot.png"
upload_to_drive(file_path, file_name)

if __name__ == "__main__":
main()

posts.com:
>>2523144
>Anybody here make their own cigarettes? Is its easy?
Yeah, it's easy to use the tube stuffing type machines if you don't want to hand roll them.
It's probably faster to use the stuffing machine too. I used the "topomatic" type machine.
>Cheaper then manufactured ones?
It's way way fucking cheaper. Do the math; you can get a pound of decent tobacco for like 15$ and tubes to go with it for another 5$ and make about 20 packs of cigarettes.
It'll probably average you around a dollar per pack or less.

One problem with doing this though is that the cigarettes won't be exactly like your favorite store brand. They won't taste exactly the same because cigarette manufacturers use a proprietary blend of flavors and treatments that is responsible for the distinct taste of their cigs. You can still find plenty of good quality, cheap tobacco (menthol, light, regular, extra bold, etc) but it will never be an exact match for your favorite brand.
Another thing is that these homemade ones will always burn just slightly differently than the industrial ones. Industrially made cigarettes are (AFAIK) made from a specially prepared reconstituted tobacco paper rather than shredded leaves. They do this to make things easier for their treatment steps, but also to make the mix have a 100% consistent texture and consistency that helps avoid problems with their processing and packing machinery. When you buy the cheap bags of raw tobacco, it's just leaves that have been cut/shredded to a consistency which is appropriate for rolling or tube packing cigs. So sometimes you may have a tiny inconsistency or packing error and wind up with a small void or an end of the tube that doesn't pack completely.

After you get familiar with the perfect amount of leaf to load in the machines chamber by doing a couple dozen cigs, you'll start to avoid this issue for the most part.

All in all, it's super cheap and easy to do and I'm always amazed that more smokers don't RYO

It can save you money, but it won't, it'll just give you the option to pop out $10-$20 cartons at will.

Fuck tubes, they're gross, and filling them yourself is a waste of time.
If you're going to roll your own, roll them. If you don't want to hand roll, there are countless tools to help.
I recommend rolling boxes, pic related. They're easy as fuck, convenient, and portable.
Need a smoke, you stop and roll a smoke instead of pulling out 5-penny cigarettes one after another.
Tubes are for filling with Bugler and selling by the carton to Tyrone and his crew.
Don't waste your time with tubes.

Those bags you see of Top and Bugler down at the gas station? Garbage, fucking nasty garbage.
Top is shit if you're not 12 years old, it's been shit for decades now.
Bugler was created as a cheap smokable cardboard for niggers in jail, genuinely, that's not a joke.
Drum is the best stuff you'll find easily, and it is pretty decent, but the shag cut and strong flavor makes it a real love-it-or-hate-it option.
From Drum, you occasionally see yellow bags, "Drum Gold." Better stuff, probably the best gas-station tobacco you'll find in the US.

Buy good tobacco.
It doesn't have all the horrors they add to boxed cigarettes to improve burn and other stupid shit.
Tobacco is bad for you, but you can't compare what you find in a bag of loose-leaf from the reservation to what's in a boxed cigarette.
If tobacco were food, the good stuff is a big red artery clogging steak, a box of Marlboro's is a McDonald's hamburger.
Neither is good for you, but you can't tell me it'd be a debate if the steak is the cheaper option of the two.

The "Natural Loose-Leaf" bulk stuff you find from the native reservations can be some of the best tobacco you'll ever find, and at insane prices too.
Major brands can still be a savings over boxed cigarettes, even if they're not the cheapest thing on the shelf.
I usually recommend Peter Stokkebye products, their Norwegian Blend is one of my favorites.

posts.com:
>>2523287
God damn I hate tubes, they are disgusting and overpriced as a motherfucker.

Anyway, a non-shit machine won't blink at any size you throw at it, it should effectively make no difference.
The little plastic shooters and mid-range one handed bandits are pretty shit, they struggle with everything and aren't worth your time.

If you're going to pop out almost 2 cartons worth per week, you're going to want something that'll keep up.
If you practice, and you get good and quick with a Top-o-Matic style injector or a handheld plastic one, sit down and do it all very rapidly in one sitting without taking a brake, that'll take about an hour.
If you aren't a spastic twat, and also aren't a fucking master of the tube injector, you'll more realistically be spending 2+ hours per week making smokes.

A decent electric filler will save you so much time and effort it's worth joking about.
I have a hard time getting excited about 'em as I despise tubes and I'm probably faster with my rolling box (which isn't hand rolling, it's a fucking machine to do the work for you) than most faggots with a tube shooter.
If you want quantity though, a good electric filler is hard to beat.
It'll pay for itself anyway with the savings on smokes, and it'll pay for itself twice over versus the headaches of cheap shitty options.

Most out there are chinkanese, and some do actually suffer with longer tubes like you mentioned.
Handheld Plastic and Lever-Handle injectors are designed for specific sizes, and rarely perform well with any other size.
An electric that has adjustable pack/fill and has an oversized fill rod that can easily clear sizes beyond 100, that's what you want.
See if you have any local tobacco shops, as opposed to a smokeshop, decent chance they'll carry the same ones you find in the tobacco catalogs and you can actually get your eyes and hands on them instead of throwing darts online.

posts.com: I use to have a few hand crank rollers, they're shit the nut always loosens and there is no torque specs on it, has to be so lose but just the right tightness that it holds the bar together but they can still move to get it to work. They work great for a bit of usage then always have the same problem. I ended up buying an electronic one for a hundred dollars to test it out. Broke even in cost within 2 months, and actually had beer money left over after that. I kept having to travel for work and going out of town it wasn't practical to ever make enough to bring with and it was noticeable how fast buying packs would burn through cash. Even though it takes 5 minutes to make a pack worth of cigarettes with it usually it isn't worth the time compared to a tobacco pipe for me personally. Your mileage may vary. It was more than worth it for me the machines worked for over 5 years now (way more than I ever got out of hand crank ones) it's nice to be able to knock out a few really fast if I'm in the mood for a cig, and they're convenient when walking around outside and it's windy on the way between the bar to pick up a few drinks. It can be difficult getting consistency in how tightly they're packed, with hand cranks you can pack a tube so tighly you basically can't keep it lit, electronic ones will jam and you can't force it and have to break it up and go with much looser packing in cigarettes, so you want to smoke them if you got them otherwise they'll tend to shake loose while you're walking around. It's not a big deal if you got a hard case you can just throw the shake back into the machine and repack it, tear off the empty part of the tube that it fell out, it can be annoying if you got like 3 half cigarettes, but you get a sense for which ones will do that and to smoke them first. If you care to carry rolling papers on you, you can always just use that shake to make a rolley too, I like a rolley when no pipe but it's hard not to burn my stache with them.

>>2524402
>The powdered stuff that you snort. Dont know the name, never tried it.
That's snuff, and it's fucking awesome.

Ozona is the most widespread brand in the US.
Their Presidential is pretty unimpressive in my opinion, the Weiss and English are much better.
The C-Type (cherry) is what I'd recommend to most first-timers as an introduction to the stuff.
You sniff a small amount, a very small amount, into your nostrils.
Just the nostrils, you're not inhaling it, just barely getting it up in there.

Of every tobacco product out there that I've tried, snuff is the closest analogue to cigarettes as far as the high they provide.
You use very, very little tobacco, and it hits you like a freight train, then wears off quickly.
It's convenient as hell, a little tin in your pocket is much smaller than a pack of smokes and won't be ruined by manhandling, and you can use it wherever the fuck because it sure as hell isn't smoke, and that includes wherever the kids with vapes aren't allowed.

Ever needed a smoke in the middle of an unimpressive movie you're sitting through with some bitch?
Ever really needed a smoke on a long flight?
Stuck in a meeting for a whole day with one fucking lunch break and no chance to take 5 and puff one?

Go buy a tin of snuff from any decent tobacco shop, usually costs less than a half-decent pack of smokes.
I'm a pack-a-day smoker, and if I'm on a business trip I won't bother with smokes, a 5g tin of snuff lasts me 5 days.
It may not replace your current preference, it sure as shit has never replaced cigarettes or cigars for me, but it is a fucking awesome addition to the line-up.

It's also worth noting, it's basically guaranteed to make you sneeze.

If she's making $150k a year, you can definitely afford a house. Life style creep is real and hard to deal with. I made 120k while my wife made 35k but now she's making close to 80k and keeps buying more bullshit. Most women are fucking retarded with money.

I use a budget tool, the one I use is You Need A Budget. I religiously tracked every expense and categorized them, and after 6 months I showed my wife what we spend our money on. It took some rough uncomfortable talks to get her to calm the fuck down with her money and make her understand that if we pay the mortgage every 2 weeks instead of monthly we will pay it off 7 years early. It took some time to show her how much we needed to save if we want to retire at 60.

You are her partner. Don't belittle yourself for making less. You can look for a higher paying job maybe on the coast where she "works" now. There may also be a tech bust sooner or later. It sucks, but you need to make her understand you're a team, have a discussion about what HER goals are, and help her reach them. If she's spending like this maybe she doesn't care about a house. Get your goals situated and help her come up with a plan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525351
Bending is a function of force and length on one hand, and stiffness on the other.
Want to reduce bending? Reduce force. You can't lower gravity, so reduce the weight first. Second, reduce length of the bending member to a minimum. If you add another file cabinet to that setup you reduce the span by a foot or so, which should cut sag by a third if not a half.
To increase stiffness, simply replace that weak wood with a one inch thick piece of steel. May need some reinforcement on the file cabinets though. Carbon fibre would be another option, but a bit expensive. Stiffness, however, is a function of both material and geometry. If you want a stiffer panel, increasing the thickness only does so much. You would make it much, much stiffer by placing a supporting beam at the rear of the panel.
Finally, you could put a leg in the middle to prevent sag altogether, but that would probably not look as good and intrude on leg room.

In all seriousness, a 1x4'' piece of wood underneath the table surface, at the wall end, should support it more than enough. Just make sure than the tabel surface overlaps the cabinets by about an inch or so, so you can screw or glue the surface and beam together.

>>2523747
Doug would of course claim that that pic just shows how needlessly complicated a typical bermuda rigged boat is and that junks are superior on that count alone but a) that's not a typical bermuda rig even for something intended for singlehanding and doesn't *need* that many lines led aft...and b) junk running rigging isn't necessarily simple, especially when set up for singlehanded operation.
Picrel is the boat of the guy who did more to advance singlehanded offshore sailing and junk rig adaptation to modern/western hull forms than anyone, just as an example of what a proper setup looks like.
He was a legendary yachtsman and pioneer in offshore sailing techology and junk rigging who proved his ideas with multiple blue water passages, I doubt that Doug would even recognize his name if he heard it.
Also worth noting that after that boat was proven seaworthy and safe in a number of Atlantic crossings, it sank on an Atlantic crossing-

"Jester competed in the first OSTAR Transatlantic race in 1960, which was won by Sir Francis Chichester in Gypsy Moth II . Jester came second. She competed in every single subsequent OSTAR, but in 1989 was seriously damaged under sail and lost."
http://www.collars.co.uk/uk_galaxy/info/1/masts_and_spars/6/the_famous_modified_folkboat_jester

Oddly enough there's a recent post on Seeker's FB from a guy who has built an all steel 42' trimaran from an old piece of chimney pipe with smaller pipes for the amas...
He's had it on the water for a few years and actually sailed it, so he's ahead of Doug in that regard, and appears far more sensible and humble even though he tends to come to Doug's defense quickly based on having been called a nut.
But like Seeker his amateur build has been fraught with hurdles and re- re- re- configuring of issues that "haters" warned him about, and his original goal of travelii around the world in it is in limbo. The design is hydrodynamically questionable but I've seen worse and it appears reasonably well built.
It's kooky as hell but he's actually doing it (sailing) and rather than being a hostile asshole he took ownership of the criticism by naming it the SV Pipedream-

"This channel is mainly about my boat Pipedream. I built this boat out of an old cooling tower ( chimney ) some years ago and I am currently trying to complete a refit and finalise modifications so that I can do some sort of trip.

There is a lot of welding, grinding, plasma cutting and painting to do and in some ways this is an abject lesson in why it is easier to just buy a boat. But for those who like to tinker and do things themselves (and are masochistic) then building is an affliction that can not be avoided.

https://m.youtube.com/@SailingSVPipedream/videos

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2516968
Time out timer (ToT) is an option that can be modified or disabled in most handhelds but they are not made for continuous txmit nor the rules allow for it. You will probably bust the ppt button or even burn the txmitter given enough battery or direct power source.
If you want to try on a cheap disposable device anyway I suggest replacing the internal push ppt button with a switch and use a low tx power.
If your intention is that to emit a beacon signal you can make use of the VOX function instead with a direct cable connection to the sound source played in a loop. It will txmit automatically but only when sound is played, leaving the freq free when not.

>>2518417
The entire point of ham radio is to experiment, test, and improve. Building radios, amps, antennas, etc. It's a hobby built around doing shit yourself. One of the coolest things you can do is pick up a basic diy radio kit to build and solder yourself. Then find an old lamp or any electrical wiring you have laying around and build a 5ft dipole. Don't worry about a balun, you're just receiving anyway. Run it straight to the radio with some wire and right out your window. 2.5ft on each side, have them hanging against the wall or something it literally does not fucking matter. The antenna could be a 15in long rusty nail from your backyard, fm broadcasts are so strong you'll probably pick shit up.

Look up qrp stations and how well they work with ft8 transmissions. Every satellite in space could be nuked right now, we'd still have world-wide radio wave communications to some degree. Our fundamental understanding of radio waves and data transmissions far exceeds most people's expectations. Building a basic transceiver on any band is something a child can do with an instruction manual and 0 experience.

>>2518417
Honestly, the hardest bit about building radios is conforming to a bunch or rules that make sure you don't piss everybody else off.

You can build a fairly powerful spark-gap morse code transmitter that you can hear all around the world on practically all frequencies form nothing but copper wire, and some iron. Hell you can pick up the transmissions with just some wire, a pencil and a razor.

That's in fact how the first radios communications where realized. The first recover used a vile with some iron shavings as a pseudo-diode.

However, if I where to to that today, everybody ant their grandmothers dog would be backing down my neck for disrupting communications.

It really depends on how much resources you have available.
If you can scramble up any form of transistors, you can build decent transmitters and receivers from shit you find around, with nothing but some math.

Capacitors can be build from aluminum foil and baking sheets, resistors are still just really thin copper wire around a ceramic core. Semiconductors get a little tricky to diy. Pure semiconductor grade shit isn't found in everyday life.
Diodes can be improvised from pencil leads and oxidized iron. GI-s used to build foxhole radios using razors and copper wire. The wire would serve as a tuning coil, while the razor-pencil combo worked well enough as a diode to pick up AM broadcasts.

Given enough time, resources and motivation I'm reasonably convinced some autist could DIY workable vacuum tubes from relatively common items. After that you're pretty much working with near enough modern electronics

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519316
On second though, now that i've started thinking about the subject, I do remember seeing people building pseudo-triodes using a burner and bits and pieces of metal to improvise an anode-cathode and grid. A sort of pseudo-vacuum tube. I'm not sure as to how effective such a device would be a for a transmitter, but admittedly limited receivers have been build around these things. With some impedance matching transformers and a lot of tinkering, maybe a transmitter could be build like this.

>i thought it was all HF too
Yea, that's the first thing that came to my mind. That's the carrot of the General license
There are weekend contests and an online log to track and confirm who many of the 340 'countries' you've worked.
>HT's with FM repeaters
Depending on your location, that's a beautiful network of helpful old men which is a very untapped resource when it comes to day to day help. Need directions? New in town and want restaurant recommendations? Car broke down and you don't have a cell phone?
Then there are technical hobbies with learning and building antennas or assembling kits or tracking balloons with APRS.
You can send text messages and emails too now without a cellphone or internet. It's so empowering and most if not all of the services are free.
>i didn't realize the depth of it
It's very deep and also disjointed. If you're in the Ohio/Indiana/Kentucky area, there's a podcast called AB4WS that gives a weekly update on what's coming up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521256
You can literally get on the air right now.
Call a nice and slow CQ, at the speed you're comfortable receiving at.. Bunch of beginners will be hogging to talk to anyone and everyone.
If somebody contacts you that's too fast ask for QRS PSE.
Just send out 599 for a few days.
Then learn full boomer QSO-s. Even if you cant get the full QSO just catch the callsign and RST. Nothing else really matters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521284
>ugh. They really are 2 separate skills.
That is the painful truth.
Beginner mistake 1: fire off a message at best speed, then get a reply at same speed, which turns out to be way too fast, ending up begging with a QRS.

Beginner mistake 2: optimistically fire off a QRQ and forgetting to specify speed, discover the other party is capable of speeds in excess of what was thought humanely possible, and once again having to submit a QRS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521284
>They offer a 15wpm feed, but I'm afraid I'll start counting instead of 'hearing' the letter.
You should be fine at 15, but don't go slower.
Keep 15/20/25 wpm files running on your commute and enjoy the moments where you pick out whole words. Do that often and regularly.

I'll suspend the larp comments since we went from a broad 'recommendations for additional gear' to innawoods with friends to now you envision you're innawoods with a chest rig.

the idea of a EFHW is that it is resonant, you only need to transform the impedance of the feed point. you don't need a tuner.
A random wire antenna is what you have in mind, it needs a tuner to be resonant.
You can use a manual tuner, but it takes longer to tune than a automatic one. For a good manual one up to ~15W look up the Emtech ZM-2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526025
Pretty difficult.
There's ALOT of stuff to learn, and it can be overwhelming. hell I've been doing it for years and I'm coming to terms I'll never understand microwaves.

That said it all depends on your prior knowledge.
If you can do some basic electronics, you should understand power and frequency. Bandwidth is well the width of the frequency band. Bandwidth also dictates how much data you can theoretically feed though a connection. Antennas rely on complex impedance. Since they aren't a straight forward conductor, rather a strange hybrid between resistor, capacitor and inductor. Well this amalgam of all three can be fed a certain amount of power at a given frequency, and depending on the complex impedance measurements the antenna will either radiate most, some or none of that energy in to the either. There's is a lot to antenna theory but this is a very plastic explanation.

Building a transmitter you'll need to get a handle on modulation and demodulation. That basically involves embedding a signal in to another signal, then having the original signal extracted at the receiving side.

Now the tricky bit with what you've described is that most RC stuff runs at ultra high frequencies. At these frequencies it gets kind of tricky to DIY modules, as the tolerances get ever tighter.

You'll want to look in to FSK modulation that is used to control most RC stuff.

You don't per say need a license if you're transmitting low power (sub 5w) , and you cant really transmit RC signals in bands designated for HAM radio.

Secondly equipment needed to diy around high frequencies gets exponentially more expensive. With 300$ you can be set for life as far as HF lab equipment goes. For UHF that wont even get you a good enough multimeter,

My suggestion is to give the Arduino RF modules a try for RC. They are cheap, and DIY enough for most people. Or get ready to a heavy investment of time and money

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527476
>So for me and my guys to avoid jamming will be enough to avoid these frequencies

See there is a rhyme and reason for using certain frequencies. Mostly it's laws and regulations, but for something like your imagining there's a whole new perspective to it.

See using 2.4Ghz, and 5Ghz to control your drone hides you in the civilian background noise... Sure that 2.4Ghz spike could be a drone operator but it could also be a phone or router in a hospital, basement, coffee shop, orphanage.
Best not shell it unless you're sure.

On the other hand, see this here spike on air traffic control frequencies there, this one right here? No where near an airport. Yeah Ivan fire op the Maлюткa, it's been sitting in storage since WW2, might as well have some fireworks.

>I could take a working transmitter and make a cool antenna

Trouble with this is that, much like everything else on higher frequencies antennas are things of precision and math. At best you kind of eye ball it, and blow up your transmitter. Secondly, most working transmitters you find are going to be designed with these frequencies in mid, and not designed with military grade transmission, recovery and integrity protocols. Hell even hill grade drones where until recently brought down by signal spoofing.

What you're describing isn't impossible, but it's not a project to be taken on by somebody who doesn't know what bandwidth is. I wouldn't trust my life on anything you DIY-ed in an active warzone, and if you do i'm looking forward to seeing your corpse posted on /k/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526941
>Why do people not to this?
I've done it... like the other anon said they are inferior on carpet without a beater bar.
They're sized for large tasks/loads and for typical home use that creates a few drawbacks-
- Not easy to empty into containers smaller than a shop/ yard style can
- more effort and hassle to dump the large barrel, but if you wait until it's full it can pick up odors, especially if you have pets
- usually don't have any way to see fill level without opening, which makes a mess
- they usually have shitty exhaust filtration and direction for use in a living space compared to a dedicated residential vac...I had to make a snorkel to direct the exhaust up or else it would blow papers and small items off of desks and low tables, blow dust and lint further under furniture and into corners the second you turned it on, toss blinds and curtains around, etc.
-We have dogs so after a while even with careful cleaning/ disinfecting it just pumped out dog bed smell that made it impossible to take into other peoples homes when doing remodel/ repair work.
-Finally the tools tend to be pretty limited, expensive when they arent, and thevtools and especially hoses are sized for shop and industrial spaces and can be unwieldy in tight areas or where you have nice finishes you dont want to bang up.
I have both now and except for cleanup after doing carpentry or drywall work or using the wet vac after a leak or flood event, the shop vac stays in the shop.

>>2509382
see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

show examples of how this could be made, 3d printers are definetevly cool, but I noticed a trend where people will simply assume that a printer can print anything. How would you measure out your face this way? I did with simple gypsum bandages. And then print it how? Carbon fibres? For costs, a 33cm x 33cm rectangle plate costs about 15€ in material costs, the groin plate has this size. thats 9 + 9 patches of the heavy a d light glass filament. 1m2 can be cut into 9 patches. 1m2 of glass weave costs about 3-5€, so about 3 for the light and 5 for the heavy, 8€ total for the weave. Epoxy resin can be expensive, cheapest I found was 11€ per kg. for a 33cmx33cm plate with 18 layers of mixed weaves I needed 750g of epoxy, so about 7-9€ or something. Now you got a basic plate for what 15-20€. Porcelain is the best worst ceramic for balistic protection, you can source that for free. Add another glass weave for spalling protection above that to stop porcelain fragments from flying everywhere and boom you got a decent plate I'd say. 25€ max.

the protective gear part is a different beast. the orthopaedic gear is to prevent knee injury from missteps or non optimal posture. same goes for the lumbar belt.
even the cheap aldi versions do their job.

joint injury is the number one eliminator of modern troops.

for the fit: add a padded comfortable belt strap with some semi-rigid plate support. this way you circumvent the spine being loaded and free your lungs more. putting padding on the shin lower side, so it rests better on the shoe, can make the bug a feature.

some light knee pads could help with the armor and hard knuckle or sand gloves would add some necessary hand protection.

for the groin plate: try to cut it int an inverted trapezoid (basicly upside down chest plate shape). then it moves more easily when walking. the two removed pieces can be added as belt flaps/ armor skirt pieces.

>>2513688
For maximum efficiency, cut the fat out and chop it into ~1cm cubes. Put it in a pot with some water to cover and heat it to a simmer. After a few hours all the fatty acids will be rendered out of the tissue, then you sift the chunks out and let the liquids harden. The fat layer separates and floats on the water. To clean it just scrape the grimy bits off the bottom of the solid fat layer and put it back in a pot with fresh water and a generous handful of salt, bring it to a simmer and stir it a bit, let it cool and repeat until pearly white. Finally melt the fat down and insert a wick. There you go, odorless human candle.
Human fat is about 7700kcal/kg which is a lot better than wood pellets which generally sit around 4300kcal/kg. You only need a small fraction of that energy to refine it.

To make soap all you need to do is weigh your human tallow, then bring it to about 50°C. Take 26.82% of your fat weight in distilled water and 13.41% in pure lye and dissolve it in the water (do it with good ventilation or die). It will heat to almost boiling so let the mixture come down to around 50°C also, then dump it in the liquid fat and blend it with an immersion blender until it turns into a sort of paste. Scoop that out into whatever mold you like and let it sit for a day, then demold it and let it air dry for 2-4 weeks.

So I actually made a plate like this when I was a teenager. I took a piece of polycarbonate, placed ceramic tiles on top and then laminated the whole thing with many layers of fiberglass and polyester resin. Then I went to a gunfag board and asked some one to shoot it for me.

The results were not good, basically the only thing that didn't penetrate fully was .22LR. I don't remember exactly what he shot it with but I recovered the jacket of a large caliber pistol, possibly 45ACP and a small rifle round, most likely .223. Simply put, ceramic tiles are not hard enough to stop rifle rounds and while they may be able to fragment pistol rounds, they then turn into shrapnel that blows right through the backing. The whole thing was too stiff to work even as 3A armor and while polycarbonate is very tough, it cannot withstand the high impulse of a bullet impact, it basically tore open like a flap and let everything through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527236
Depends on what you can change.
>Renting
You're fucked, landlords problem
>Buying
Replace old insulation with either foam closed cell or rock wool, new windows, new doors, weather seal doors and windows, caulk along exterior siding base to prevent drafts, check draft gates in external vents, insulate attic by piling up rock wool or blow in
>building
Use 2x6 studs for exterior walls, fill with spray foam close cell or rock wool. On exterior of house, add another layer of foam board insulation between OSB and siding. 3 pane windows standard, all external doors should be filled fiberglass (not steel).
for added fun: Orient your house so that the front door is facing south in the northern hemisphere, or north in the southern hemisphere. paint the front door black, and install steel awnings over every window. In the winter, the sun will be low on the horizon and hit the black door, transferring heat inside. In the summer, the high-noon sun will be blocked by the steel awning and the door/windows will remain cool. If you're going to do this, use a steel exterior door instead of fiberglass. My front door is basically a space heater in the winter because of this principle. If you can't face the front of the house towards the winter sun, face the back and make the back door have the same principle.
Also: Make sure your attic is vented in the summer with a blower to prevent it from heating the house, but the vents can be closed/turned off in the winter to allow the sun to keep the space above warm. Attics might sound nice as storage but what's better is as much insulation as you can layer up there, I'm talking 24-36 inches thick over everything. fuck it.

The key is to basically pack in as much insulation as possible and eliminate air leaks, while at the same time increasing the thermal mass of your house to prevent wildly fluctuating temperatures.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528520
usually there is an external breaker box that cut powers to the entire house that is placed outdoors at the mains connection. This is to protect the house in the case a short happens before reaching the junction box, which is always inside the houses. I am not an electrician, so I don't know if this is a standard and true for all homes, but it is true in my case. If you want to replace the outdoor junction box, then you might have to call the power company if there isn't a cutoff siwtch somewherre.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Actual glass fabricator here.
Tempered glass is not the go to material for table top whether in a frame or with floating edges, because it doest like edge damage *at all* and also doesn't like concentrations of heat like you get in typical table uses.
Tempered glass is notorious for shattering with small concentrated point impacts and tables get those all the time from dropped utensils, tableware, etc.
The other thing is that tempering has to be done after any edge profiling is done so doing it risks all that labor. It's also done in an oven and can leave marks where the glass is supported and other imperfections that don't work well with something that needs optical clarity like a display case.

The way you get table capable glass strength is by using thick annealed glass, and 1/4"-5/16" is perfect for that kind of perimiter framed box, but not thinner. 1/2" is adequate for free standing di ner table and desk tops up to about 48" in any dimension and after that it starts to sag under its own weight.

Bottom line is that if a glass table or desk or display case breaks from dropping something on it you dont want everything else on it to dump at once into a pile of glass bits. If you chip an edge with annealed glass you can re-grind it or polish it out or cut a strip off, tempered just explodes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524432
Replacement generally has to be done the way the chair was originally done, if it used mat than you use mat, if it was woven than you weave it. Mat is simple, like replacing window screen but when it starts to fail it goes quickly. Woven is more work, a little cheaper and if a strand or two breaks the chair will generally not care much. So rip the cane completely out of one and see if it has holes or a groove. Order the supplies and have at it, expect a chair or two to be failures before you get the technique down. If you are weaving then I would get a book, having those nice color photos well arranged with descriptions of the process well arranged and laid out for you to reference while you work will be very helpful. Most libraries should have a caning book or a chair making/repair book or a canoe making book (canoes often have woven cane seats so your butt can dry out). Videos will suck for this since you will find you need to jump back and fourth a lot. You should be able to do all 8 for less than what that guy was charging for one, but you should also be able to find someone cheaper to do it, try upholstery shops. Caning chairs is enjoyable and not a bad skill to learn. Personally I prefer rush seats.
