posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I inherited the chairs. All the caning is destroyed so i can´t really make this worse. The shellack is destroyed aswell usually scratched. Not all chairs have the same finish etc.
The steps I intend to do are the following:
1. Take photos, remove caning
2. Clean chairs with water and thin solution of dish soap
3. Clean chairs with rubbing alchohol
4. Check if further repairs are necesarry,
if yes I will use boneglue. Old boneglue will be dissolved in hot water.
5. I really dont want to use abrassive media if necesarry on the surfaces. Preferrably I want to keep the patina. But if the surface is really mared I will do so
6. I will oil the chairs with a base oil (grundieröl)
7. I will use a Bimsmehl and 1:6 diluted shellack to close open pores in the surface. (Probably need 3-4 applications, and at least 12 hours of drying time) very very light sanding with a 400 grit paper inbetween.
8. applications of shellack (1:4 dilution)
9. apply polishing oil
10. remove polishing oil
11. buf
12. add caning

Inspecting the chairs it became clear to me further work needed to be done.

Good quality caning material dont seem to be very expensive. Comparibly other wood surface products are quite more expensive. Material for 2 chairs is bellow 30€/$.

My intention is not to add a very high gloss finish. At least not on all chairs. Only to replicate the original coating.

I wish all you guys a merry christmas!
Thanks for your answers.

>>2524437
Fireplaces are easier to build, to use, and to afford. A mass of iron needed for a wood stove was out of the reach of anyone except the very rich before the industrial revolution, and the metal piping needed to take the exhaust outside. The modern fireplace was invented in the medieval era using cheap, affordable materials like stone and brick, could be integrated easily into a building, and removal of the exhaust was implicit and effecient. You could also build larger fires in a hearth, wood stoves are limited in size, because of the complexity and cost of casting large amounts of iron.
A wood stove has two uses: radiant heat, and cooking. A fireplace has more uses, like providing a source of light for a room/hall. People were also using masonry to build ovens in northern Europe for heat/cooking.

So why did they keep building them, autist? Because they had more use and were more efficient, and being able to scale the fireplace to the space, unlike an expensive, hard scale cast iron piece. The world isn't an either/or proposition, people build and use what's practical, affordable, and more efficient. I know your autism lashes out at that idea, but that's your problem, not ours.

>>2525202
>Hiring a good mason to build the fireplace costs more than buying a wood stove
Masons themselves are not really the expense, more the materials.
>So it's always important to get it built by someone who knows what they're doing.
It is actually more important to get it designed by someone who knows what they are doing. Unless you live in the middle of nowhere or the 3rd world you can not just hire a mason and tell them to build you a chimney, have to submit plans and all that for permitting. So you hire an architect to design and then most any mason will be able to build it, masons tend to be good at following plans.
>Wood stove is more practical in all other ways
Live somewhere that regularly gets down to -40 below, having that large masonry mass heated up and those big slow burning logs is quite nice for getting you a full nights sleep and not waking up freezing. Wood stove you can not let go out for any amount of time in such conditions or you will end up burning through a huge amount of wood getting the houses temperature back up. Heat rises. Smoke is hot. Hot smoke would rather go up the flue the into the room. That said, a shitty fireplace will blow smoke into the room. There's a ratio between the size of the flue and the size of the opening to the room that has to be respected.

As pointed out, electric heaters are, for all intents and purposes, 100% efficient. It doesn't matter which one you get, it's not possible for any of them to "waste" electricity; heat IS the waste product in all other electronics.

You can get one of the meme fireplaces if you want, it won't make a difference in your heating bill either way. You could get a heat pump, which is substantially more efficient (and expensive) than a plain-old resistive electric heater.

House I grew up in had a real wood burning fireplace. Had fans built into the brick somehow, 2 vents on either side, so there was an intake down low, and would suck air in close to the flue and blow it out the outlet vents. Regular fire with no fans running didn’t put out much heat, but turn those fans on and you could cut the furnace.

Don’t know how many fireplaces have that as the majority I have seen in houses are fake or run natural gas through these gay fake logs. I fuckin loved building fires on snowy nights up there, but I love Florida with 70 degree winters even more. I still have a couple bricks from that fireplace I’ve kept with me.

posts.com:
>>2525135
Pressure naturally wants to go from high to low. Air pressure down closer to the ground is higher than air pressure up high at the top of the chimney, so air gets sucked up there. That's what a draft is. A temperature difference exacerbates the pressure difference, so you can get a better draft by heating your chimney with a small piece of kindling before moving on to bigger logs.

>>2516819
Then apply at an electrical company for an apprenticeship. Apply at a few of them. Commercial would be best because that's what most of the code book is. Then either industrial or service work. Service, you'll learn repair and more about electricity in general. Residential new construction is a fast paced game where only the fastest person is fast and everyone else is slow, every job is bid under every other residential company because Fuck quality workmanship, only a few chapters in the code book are needed for the job , so you won't learn much. I started out in residential, because of my father getting me a job and doing side work since I was 12 or so, and trying to learn the code with out ever seeing a transformer, main distribution panel, running conduit and shit like that, it was hard to understand what all the codes were even talking about. Got my journeyman, quit residential and went commercial. Then 2008 happened and commercial shut down in my area. Had to go back to residential and work for a dipshit, who I think sucked a LOT of dicks to get where he was at. That pissed me off enough to get my contractors and start my own company. I do high end remodel now. Have to use my brain troubleshooting and planning and I enjoy that. The only drawback is attic work occasionally.

Figure out how high you want to go and get a job in that field. Figure out what you like doing as well. Industrial is different than commercial is different than residential. A lot of guys are just happy with a paycheck and don't mind running conduit and pulling circuits forever. Some want to move up to foreman. Some, can't do the job and they get stuck roughing in walls and devicing out.

Hey, it sounds like you've had some success fixing things around the house on your own, and you're wondering if you should consider becoming a mechanic. It's definitely possible that you have the skills and aptitude for this kind of work, and it can be really satisfying to be able to fix things yourself. However, it's worth noting that not all repairs are as straightforward as the ones you've tackled so far, and some might require specialized tools or training. Plus, it's important to consider whether you'd actually enjoy working as a mechanic - the work can be physically demanding and sometimes involve working in dirty or uncomfortable conditions. So before you make any big career decisions, it might be worth taking some time to think about whether this is the right fit for you.

posts.com: /diy explain. loosing pressure from my refilled fire extuingisher. Drilled hole for a bicycle valve, filled about 3/4 with hot water, screwed trigger back on, pumped air into it up to 8,5 bar (where green starts on the manometer). Now everytime I check the pressure has decreased slightly. Is that expected from bicycle valves? I've to pump up our bikes every 2-3 months too. Is there something like a type of air leak glue? I tried to seal the valve with E6000 in my first attempt, but it didn't work properly. Then I got a sealing ring and a washer which did it for now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526527
The valve is cut out of a bicycle tube with some leftover rubber on the sides, inserted into the extuingisher. The ring screw presses against the washer which also squeezes the sealent ring. Tried without the washer, but that procedure broke my first sealent ring.
>>2526532
that's a good info with the soap water. Never worked much with sealing and pressure stuff before.
>and then fix where the bubbles are coming from
but how? What is it called? sealement glue? Does something like this exist? Something that doesn't make the rubber ring porossus or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526581
So it's just a rubber bicycle valve stem pushing against the inside of the hole ... and that hole is probably about as "smooth" on the inside as it is on the outside.
Honestly I'm surprised it only leaks as little as it does.

You may want to try using RTV or some kind of gasket-maker on the inside of the hole and around the valve stem before you tighten it up.
But the best way to do this would be to weld a threaded bung onto the tank then thread a valve stem into it with pipe sealant, and not rely on a cut up rubber bicycle tire to hold air.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2528410
Based CO2 extinguisher mod^

Instead of adding dip tubes I retain my cylinders as vapor withdrawal units for MIG shielding gas, tire inflation in the field and bead seating and to run an impact in a pinch at high pressure. Fancy version, I just use a regulator/hose/brass pneumatic chuck etc.

https://trail4runner.com/2020/06/21/diy-power-tank-co2-tank-airing-up-tires/

They do serve as extinguishers by inverting them Of course your now-liquid-withdrawal cylinders can be used for vapor withdrawal applications by inverting them.

I also collect other industrial gas cylinders. I use nitrogen for HVAC work ( the first job I did on my truck paid for the tools and I've done several since), I use MIG mix and argon for welding but you can and I have pressure checked HVAC systems with those more expensive gases so no need for nitrogen if you don't do a lot of that stuff. I use oxygen for oxy-LP and oxy-actylene cutting/brazing/welding.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2528440
I bought one of these several years ago based on the certainty I would eventually need it. I accumulate BBQ jugs because only one cylinder means when that one runs out you will have downtime which of course is not acceptable.

https://www.sportsmansguide.com/product/index/mr-heater-forced-air-propane-heater-60000-btu?a=1835683

Storm froze one water line feeding my water heater despite it being insulated so I aimed propane heater at that section of wall (the line is outside the house and will remain that way for maintenance convenience) and thawed the line. You can use forced air heaters in many ways by deflecting the air to your target. These are handy as fuck and likely in stock even during storm conditions. The blower can be powered off an inverter connected to your car or truck if grid shuts down or of course by a generator.

I take lessons learned notes after every serious weather incident then correct any problems since it's reasonable to expect shit will happen again.

Tip for anything LP, buy a bag of hose connector O-rings online and tape it to your heater or other device so you never lose it. In other news I don't buy toilet paper by the sheet.

>>2504840
i'm an arborist by profession.
Even modern high quality chains break from time to time. either from misuse, accident or material fault. on average a chain snaps on me every one to two years. luckily modern chainsaws have a chain catcher under the clutch so even when a chain should snap it will immediately arrest on the catcher as it leaves the bar on the underside and be stopped at the catcher immediately - if you are lucky - just dropping down from the catcher harmlessly or slapping the hand guard on the rear grip where it will lose its momentum.
in the worst of cases one of the chain links will get caught and the rest of the chain will come whipping around on the underside of the bar - miss the hand guard and slap the underside of your rear arm, upper leg or your hip if you are holding the saw sideways.
in any case its going to be like a 35mph whip with teeth but it wont keep running and actually be pulled through your flesh as it hits you. wounds from this should be superficial due to the chain loosing most of its energy on the catch.

should you ever pick up a saw with this safety feature missing or damaged, do not use it!

Maybe you do, but witnessing the repercussions of bad decisions and truly unforseeable mishaps like tool and material flaws creating instantaneous danger and havoc makes lots of people far more cautious and methodical in their work, and far less likely to succumb to ridicule or pressure from higher ups to cut corners.
>And it also turns out that when you do something for a job, you get tend to get tired and your mind wanders.
Again, speak for yourself...if anything people with lots of experience know better when to take breaks or stop when fatigued, and understand better than anyone how to stay focused and why it's important.
You're just pulling stuff out of your ass to support your personal biases and assuming that correlation equals causation when it comes to experience and industrial accidents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523532
>that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable
yes that is literally how statistics work, if you have a p chance of not cutting your finger off and n number of opportunities to cut your finger off then the probability that in your life you cut your finger off is p^n. This function approaches 0 and for a sufficiently large n always ends with you cutting your finger off. Having a larger number of times where you don't cut a finger off is not going to undo the one time it does happen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527369
Depends on your jurisdiction, but any scale legal "for trade" generally needs to support calibration. In some jurisdictions, you might even need a licensed specialist to calibrate it regularly and certify it.
The cheaper scales you get off Amazon or whatever won't support calibration. They will probably work fine, but you probably can't use it as evidence in a legal dispute or whatever (but in that case, you might as well just find a business with a certified scale and ask them to take a measurement).

But, yeah, if you are looking for a "high quality" scale, the first box you should tick off is "can it be calibrated?" Followed by "supports the weight range I want" and "has the precision I want."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521478
>Could a person get some of those baofeng radios and operate them as a base station on CB frequencies (so I don't have to get an operators license)
No, you cannot. Memefeng can't do 27mhz, lowest it goes is like 140 or so.
Ref the loicence question, I assume you are in the burgerland. Here's something you can do that is technically illegal, but your chances of getting caught are very low:
Set your baofengs to broadcast on a GMRS or FRS channel but at maximum wattage (5 or 8 depending on model)
Then, set them to use a privacy code, further reducing your chances of either pissing anyone off or getting caught.
Because you're on GMRS which is basically a free for all, nobody is likely to give a fuck, even though you're using more wattage than is legally allowed there.
Alternatively you could try using an actual CB radio, but they're a bit of a different beast.

posts.com:
What you are holding there is the cladding from an uranium fuel rod, most likely a souvenir from a decommissioned nuclear reactor. They are usually encased in a shielded container and only taken out for educational purposes, with appropriate protection, as they can still be quite "hot" for decades after removal.

Uranium is twice as dense a lead, that's why it is so incredibly heavy.

For proof, here's me holding one that has been decontaminated and is well intact.

Yours appears to be slightly darker in color and shows a significant amount of wear, which indicates that the chromium coating (the shiny finish) has started to erode over time.

This is not good, and you really do not want to hold that with your bare hands.

Do these have a window on the side to see inside to see whether they're blown?
If not, the only way to know is to test.

Testing means using them in another circuit to test continuity.
You could use a multimeter with a continuity check mode
You could put them into a different spot in the fuse block
You could make a circuit with a battery and a wire and a small light bulb (like from a flashlight)

Another way to test is to stick two wires into a wall socket, and touching them to the sides of the fuse. If the lights turn off, the fuse was good. If they stay on, you have a dead fuse.

Surely there's some homeowners here?

Anyway, to start off I have a few questions for the /diy/ anons who know a little about architecture.
I'm thinking of removing the vent tubing and putting some flooring down in my loft, as well as insulating under the roof tiles and replacing the ceiling insulation. Is there a way I could remove the spars running through the middle of the roof space and reinforce the beams they support to give me an open attic, or am I stuck with them?

Also what are some good ways to try and keep my roof space cool during summer? It's stinking hot in there and I want to do something about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526257
>Surely there's some homeowners here?
No, we're an 80/20 mix of mom's basement shitposters and schizo park-bench dwellers.

> Is there a way I could remove the spars running through the middle of the roof space and reinforce the beams they support to give me an open attic, or am I stuck with them?
Is that your attic in the pic? If so, why fucking bother with such a short space?
But in a lot of wood framed gabled attics, the ceiling joists form a system which prevent the walls from spreading out horizontally due to snow or gravity loads pushing down on the triangle of the roof... There's also commonly "rafter ties" (googe image search it) which are the horizontal members visible in your pic. Rafter ties act in tension to keep the rafters from vertically being pulled up off of the ridge during a wind event. You can often replace them by using ridge straps instead (galvanized metal straps that fasten the upper ends of each pair of rafters together over or across the ridge)

If you have roof trusses up there, then odds are that NO you can't just cut the members out in the middle lol. Or you could with either reckless abandon or some idea of the engineering involved.

>Also what are some good ways to try and keep my roof space cool during summer?
White roof surface helps a lot apparently. Adequate venting will help too but it's harder to do if you're trying to convert an already built and inadequately vented attic space into a conditioned space.
Just adding more insulation to the attic floor will probably help more than using a ventilation fan would.

There's also a system where you run a pipe along the ridge on top of the roof and spritz some water on the roof surface to provide evaporative cooling. Apparently this can often keep your attic 40F cooler while using ~20 gallons a day.

>>2526257
To remove those ties, you would need to replace the ridge (the board running along the peak that the top of all the rafters attach to) with a stronger ridge beam capable of supporting the roof load from end to end. And each end of that ridge beam would need to have a post supporting it down to the foundation. If you give me the two dimensions I can tell you what size that beam needs to be.

Another large concern, perhaps even more of a concern than the roof, would be is the existing ceiling platform capable of supporting the required floor load for a living area? I'd bet that it's not, and that board that's running perpendicular to the ceiling joists is a mid-span support that was used because otherwise the joists would be spanning too large a distance even just for a ceiling/attic load with no living area on top of it. What size and spacing are those ceiling joists, and how long is the span? It would likely be the same as dimension B for the roof above.

Biggest improvement for the money is a ridge vent. Your roof appears to be sheet metal, that may be a problem, in which case a couple of roof vents will be a good choice.
Soffit vents will help.

Next is a radiant barrier on the underside of the rafters,
(which require an airspace to work)

then add more insulation before you put down flooring,

Another option that takes Way less work: Only use part of the attic for storage -put in sheet insulation in between the joists and put in a floor. Blow in a big pile of insulation everywhere else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Assuming the switch works you can tap off the hot going to the switch and the neutral that's mostly likely spliced in there. I don't know why that outlet wouldn't work in the first place.
You'll need to open the box if you want step by step instructions.
>>2528033

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528033
Is that switch a shut off for the furnace or.for the outlet? If it's for the outlet rewire the incoming directly to the outlet and scrap the switch. If it's a cutoff for the furnace you could wire the incoming to the outlet, then the outlet to the switch, but check the wattage needed for both the furnace and your gas detector to make sure you're not above the amperage for the circuit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528034

I think it's a code thing. The circuit is supposed to be dedicated to the furnace and not provide power for anything not vital to HVAC operation. However, my little detector obviously takes less power than a humidifier or other accessory.

>>2528035

I like a .9 or .7 pencil. Brand doesn't really bother me that much. I got a fisher space pen q4 which I needed for the different colors. You can only get a .7 on that and it breaks often.

If you're in a math class you want 2 or 3 colors of lead in separate pencils.

Mediun to fine gel pens or space pens are ideal.

High flow or ultra fine tip or nib pens are problematic if you ever need to sign a carbon copy.

A lot of pen shit is interchangeable there's only like 3 standards, Parker cartridges, and then the two other refill sizes. You can even get a pencil tip for pens

>>2527584
Does vinegar kill grease ants?
Vinegar doesn't really kill ants but it will certainly repel them away from your home. Ants can't stand strong smells and vinegar also negates pheromone trails which they produce to communicate. Without pheromone trails, ants won't be able to come back to your house.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How do you get rid of butter ants?
Most available ant baits must be mixed with a grease or oil to make them attractive to grease ants. Any grease or oil that can be mixed with the bait should be effective. I suggest vegetable oil, peanut butter or a raw pie dough mixture of shortening and flour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526785
Find their nest outside and pour boiling water on it. You have to do this multiple times though, during the initial deluge you'll kill a lot of them but the heat won't penetrate to the very bottom of the colony with the queen and eggs so they'll come back unless you wait a few hours so the surviving workers can begin tunneling to those areas and bringing the eggs and queen to the surface to save them from the flooded caverns (that will still have some residual heat) go back again and continue to trickle boiling water in their entrances - be sure not to pour it too fast because the tunnels will collapse again, just fast enough that is continuously absorbed into the ground.

At that point the heat and water will have killed their queen, majority of workers, and the next generation of workers. I've never had an ant colony come back after this. Plus it's nontoxic and you'll see birds feasting on the carnage after

>>2526403

I work as a handyman and literally just did this exact job.

First buy 2 stair toppers, real wood. They should be wider than what you have, you can cut them to fit later. Also get a 2x4 and some white paint and some wood stain.

Take off your current tops. Keep the support under your upper top piece. Use the 2x4s to extend your base step a little. Then screw your tops back to the steps. You can reuse your upper support. You will need flush wood sides of your steps, without gaps, for the final steps to look good.

Put wood filler in where you screwed your tops down. Then stain the wood tops. Then paint the rest of the steps in white, the fronts and the sides.

Will look classy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519695
I don't believe you will get a satisfactory result by coating the entire device in luminescent material. The substance would be radiating light over top of the printed surfaces. This is a much different effect than shining a light on a reflective surface. It would be more akin to the glare of light on a monitor, where-in the monitor is trying to emit light, but the surface of the screen is reflecting light in front of the monitor's light. It would wash out the printed letters on the keyboard and make them unreadable.
Perhaps that is okay, if you are a touch-typist and not trying to read the keyboard. But if that were the case, why would you be asking for a lighting solution? The keyboard appears to already have the usual tactile markers for hand placement.
But I think you'd get a much better effect by just detail painting in the accents you need lighted, like the printed letters on each key.

Furthermore, luminescent materials are not "free energy." They do require something to power them.
Some do retain the charge imparted by exposure to UV light and release it gradually after being removed, but the effect of relying on the very limited energy capacity of the coating will likely be underwhelming.
There are radio-luminescent materials like tritium paint. You will pay accordingly for the quality, but these do last several years.
But, ultimately the most DIY feasible solution is just to apply phosphorescent paint that reacts to UV light, and then use a UV light to illuminate it. You will obviously need to power the UV light source, but this is not a difficult DIY problem to solve. You could just put a headlamp on for the purpose.

Actually, why NOT just wear a fucking headlamp, perhaps with a red filter to be less offensive in the dark? Better than fucking about with paint and shit.

Garbage collection is privatized the world over, even in the few places where it is still a public service (like it was 300 years ago), it's typically just a publicly-owned company, which is NOT a government organization and is NOT paid by tax dollars.

Britfags trash is mostly handled by their local council and paid for with their tax-pounds.

>>2527267
There's no great way in a finished house. Basically just vacuum all the floors a couple times, with a wet vac if possible, then use a very mildly damp cloth on all the walls, and finally on all horizontal surfaces.

If your vacuum doesn't catch the dust, you'll probably need to just turn off the heat and set up a fan in an open window, open another window to get a draft moving through the house, then use the vac to kick up the dust (starting from the room farthest from your exhaust fan).

Alternatively, you could just thrown down a little cash for a decent HEPA unit, then wait out the dust.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: That's an LG isn't it. Make sure you didn't install the float upside down

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526350
Also check the pump that's attached to it. It's got a filter that gets clogged and will burn the pump up. And on the floor housing, make sure you follow the directions it says on the front, one side has a magnet. Your float switch also has a filter in it that gets clogged. Take it all apart, clean filter in switch and in pump and put it back together. If the magnet gets hard water crud on it, it doesn't function correctly and doesn't signal the pump to work. Also those pumps are small, and very prone to overheating and burning up. Ive installed a few hundred LG mini split systems and they have that exact float. Always better to not fight gravity and drain normally but sometimes you gotta pump it up and out. Please like and subscribe if this was helpful

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527066
>thats not gonna make much difference
I agree. The way flex duct is routed usually doesn't have much of an impact on static pressure since it typically goes in long smooth bends.

Most static pressure is caused either by the ribbing inside the flex ducting, or by the duct system being too small for the amount of air the unit is pushing out. You could replace the flex ducts with hard lines, but it's not really worth the time and effort since it's only just barely above the recommended pressure. Same could be said for increasing the duct size.

I guess you could just lower the fan speed a little if you really wanted to just get the pressure down into recommended spec.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525662
What you're talking about is a (gravity fed) drip irrigation system, and the design principles and technical ratings for the various types of tubing and emitters used in those systems are all about maintaining and regulating flow rates.
I think you're a bit mixed up about the basics though, the scenario you describe isn't really a problem since the outlets are sized to develop back pressure that lets the entire line fill up In a gravity fed system the overall pressure will fluctuate with the reservoir height, but if the lateral line that taps off the barrel is level and the holes small enough to create back pressure, that pressure will be the same along its entire length.
You'll need to determine the max. flow rate of the full barrel dumping out the outlet pipe unrestricted to start, then size the emitter flow rates and how many to determine how fast it will empty and also how fast it can fill up before overflowing.
Because those drip holes are tiny, filtration is important, little bits of dirt or already growing inside the hoses can easily block them and throw the flow rates way off or disable a branch line entirely.
There's a lot of variables and with gravity feed even more since the pressure changes as the barrel level goes up and down. Just read up on drip irrigation system design or talk to a place that sells the parts and it wont be that hard to get something working.

https://school.sprinklerwarehouse.com/design-install/designing-your-drip-irrigation-system/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525662
>how large the holes should be to help distribute the water through the pipe so it all just doesn't dump out the first hole or two?
If you make the holes on the top of the pipe instead of the bottom it shouldn't matter, as the pipe would need to fill up before the water started coming out of it, which should make it far more likely to evenly distribute the water.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525662
Roof area times rainfall per unit area per second divided by total cross section of pipe should be < 5 feet/s

Pick a pipe diameter and rain intensity, calculate flow speed in pipe as above, calculate head loss (google, depends also on if pipe is straight or not). The head loss found is equivalent to how high the barrel will fill up.

>Is PVC a reliable structural material
Sure. But it's not magic. Spans and suck will still sag relative to thickness and length and so forth. The hardest part is probably going to come from engineering with tubes rather than solid material. E.g. you can just go drilling into it without compromising the structural integrity -- the all is all you got.
But you're probably asking about UV. Slap some paint on it if you're worried about multi-decade survival. Like anything else.

posts.com: This is my set up to mix and bag (dry) cement, limestone and plaster. I make this for a business. I usually just dump the mixed load into the tote, hoist it up onto a table and manually scoop out enough powder until it’s the right weight (4.5lbs). I would like to speed this process up somehow, but am too much of a brainlet to figure out how to automate the bagging of compressible powders such that the weight remains within an acceptable window (approx 4.5-4.6lbs).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2527417
Yea it's not very accurate
If you want accuracy then you need to fork out some money for a system you'd see in manufacturing which would be a valve feeding a bad tied to a load cell and when you reach your weight it shuts off the valve. Vakes I've worked with are called starvalves which is motorized and rotates so you get a controlled flow

>>2523464
I don't consider myself an engineer, as I've never completed any formal education to that extent. I have a lifetime of hobbying and 20yrs of professional experience, though.
Because of the influx of pajeets, there's only a few ways left to make money in this field.
From worst to best:
>green energy
Those windmill and solar companies are always hiring. Heavy pajeet/chingchong competition. Low salary. Harsh deadlines. Etc.
Unless you aren't afraid of heights. If you can complete the physical training, them guys that climb the windmills and do maintenance/repairs make serious bank. (Same for cell towers.) $100k to start, for sure. $250k-ish within 10 years.
>electronic repair shops
These guys always need engineers on hand to build test stands and stuff. There's always a customer who has a cratefull or a truck full of some board or unit that he constantly needs to have repaired and needs 100% reliability. It's your job to figure out what the unit is, what it does, and how to completely test its functionality. This can involve anything from 'simple' reverse-engineering and building a fixture, to replicating an entire system using known-good parts and using that to validate the DUT. Starting salary depends on your area. You should easily be at $100K+ with five years of good performance.
These places are neat, because there's a lot of overlap with the rest of the categories. And it can overlap with doing field-service work, which always pays waaay more than bench work.
(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523819
(2/2)
>automotive/transportation general
I spent some time years ago at a tier-1 supplier's R&D facility. The parking lot was full of Range Rovers, Porsches, Corvettes, and the like. Even as a tech, I was salaried at $70k walking in the door. Situation is even better working directly for the automaker.
Public transit is also a growing industry in the US. Streetcars, electric trains, and subways are coming to every state if they're not already there.
>academia/scientific research
Not top-tier in salary, necessarily, unless you're Professor Shekelgruber, PhD., chair of whatever department. But here's the thing:
These people do not give one fuck about a time clock. There's no punching in and out. There's no bell or buzzer to let you know you're allowed to take a piss. All they care about is the work. Make your own schedule all the way, but you do have to meet or exceed project demands. Most days are 4-8hrs if you keep a 5-day schedule. Sure, there can be 14-16hr days or worse, but they're rare.
Can you do the work? Perfectly? The first time and every time? If something isn't right, can you figure out what? Can you concoct a way to fix it now and going forward? Can you document your findings, prepare a presentation, and sell the idea to a bunch of MEs and PhDs in a Zoom room who all know the project 10x better than you do?
You might not make mad bank, but man, you'll be free. You'll still be on the cutting edge of technology and working way past the state of the art.

That's it, really. Otherwise, you've wasted the last 4-6 years of your life. Maybe go into business for yourself, but with nothing but booksmarts, you'll just shit the bed.

>1. Is there any real reason to spend big on a "high security" lock over your stock-standard cylinder? Are thieves really picking locks in the real world?
We've had business owners at my work ask us to put high-security locks on buildings with floor-to-ceiling glass walls and doors. The security level of your lock should match the security level of the rest of your security system. Most actual criminals (in America) don't bother to pick locks because it's a skill that requires patience, and if criminals had patience, they wouldn't be criminals. They're going to put in the least amount of effort possible. Your advantage as a homeowner is that you can control how high that lower limit is.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2518012
>Are thieves really picking locks in the real world?
not much, but what some theives do is make copies of keys from where they work after getting access to them legitimately as part of their job or by sneaking them off the premises and putting them back after getti g copies made.
Security locks minimize the ability to do this by restricting and documenting who gets blanks at the locksmith level, so if you keep close rein on who has a key you can minimize inside theft jobs by unknowns or disgruntled terminations using a spare key.
If a key gets away though you'll need to get new cylinders and keys, and some brands will remove restrictions on older blanks when they stop selling those models, or just after a decafe or so to force everyone to upgrade cylinders to maintain the security restrictions.
IOW its kind of like a subscription service that needs to be renewed.

>>2518012
>Is there any real reason to spend big on a "high security" lock over your stock-standard cylinder?
For a house, no. Stay away from bullshit electronic smart locks. A lot of them can be beaten with rare earth magnets, plus the backup cylinders are baby-tier easy to pick. I've seen people open fingerprint locks with a photocopy of someone's fingerprint. Just get a regular Schlage and remember to keep it locked.

>How difficult is it to replace a lock yourself, without having to pay a locksmith?
Very easy. All you need is a phillips screwdriver. Take the long screws out of the old one, pull it apart, replace the guts, slap the new one on and line it up, screw back together. I can do them in about 15 minutes.

>>2518024
This. Get a nice solid door, dead pin the hinges, and reinforce the frame to discourage kicking in.
Add some sort of basic alarm system. They even have sensors now that will alarm and text your phone if the door is opened. The more bullshit the crackheads have to get through the less likely they are to try.
Keep your drapes closed so they can't case your house or see your bigass TV. Don't put boxes from expensive things in your trash, find a dumpster somewhere to toss them in. Don't advertise that you have shit worth stealing. Make sure sliding doors and windows have nigger bars wedged in them so they can't be forced from outside.

>>2518096
Follow basic common sense. When you buy a new house change the locks immediately before you do anything else. You have no way of knowing how many people have the old keys.
For businesses make sure you get keys back if you fire someone and cancel their alarm codes as soon as they leave. For job boxes and other storage locks replace all of the locks a couple times a year. Don't reuse old locks just pitch em. Security cameras with offsite storage are a good idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Power, Water, Heating, Cooling, Septic.
What's the best way to handle the big five off-grid?

>Power
Hydro is king, but flowing water is uncommon. Solar is weak and requires several parts that eventually need replacement. When power is abundant you get secondary systems for heating/cooling/etc. This one is hard.

>Water
Rainwater catchment? A water tower or attic water tank for gravity fed water? Maybe an underground cistern so it won't freeze, but then you lack gravity assistance.

>Heating
Can't beat wood. A secondary system should be in place, but a wood stove provides efficient heat and a cooking surface. Easy.

>Cooling
Hardest on the list. There is no simple wood stove-esque equivalent for cooling. Geothermal has promise but it's underpowered and expensive to install.

>Septic
Dead easy. You can put in your own tanks and outhouses just fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519243
Such vague answers, you must be specific in your utilization of say "wood". ie. A masonry stove? A normal metal wood stove? Also lacking here is the actual structure these will be used in, which plays the biggest roll in them succeeding.

As this anon said >>2519257
Site location and climate are the most important factors. If you have lots of sun, you will use sun, if you have a year round flowing river you could use a wheel for power.

In my climate, northern zone 5-6

>Power
Solar likely supplemented by some wind, the goal would be to reduce all other electrical uses and be very efficient.

>Water
Well would be easiest and cheapest vs. a buried cistern

>Heating
Masonry stove to supplement passive solar gains on a well insulated south facing structure along with proper roof overhands to stop summer sun.

>cooling
Solar protection via deciduous tree cover. In the winter I could absorb sunlight and in the summer be in the shade. Passive cooling can also be achieved via clever ventilation, ie. a black painted vent pipe high above my roof with some lower hanging windows opened. If I was built into a berm, I'd consider a ground pipe to pull cool underground air.

>Septic
Would depend on the number of people in the home. 2 people, I'd probably go with a composting toilet and call it a day. Grey water can go into a makeshift septic field without a proper poop tank.

>The important thing you left out - STRUCTURE
all these systems 100% work or fail based on the structure. You wont need a high thermal mass stove if you've build a cocoon of an insulated structure, since overheating will occur. My plan would be IDEALLY something like picrel, a bermed house facing south with an array of windows on that south face for winter gains. The roof would need to be angled to shade things out in summer. Structure would be concrete with some strong interior buttresses to hold back that buried rear wall. All concrete, foam, liner and dirt.

Having an abundance of electricity is far easier and rarely requires any external sourcing aside from equipment.
Propane not only require external sourcing of fuel, the residential style refrigerators available aren't particularly well made or well insulated despite their cost and purported off grid target market.
IF you had a ready supply of propane and used it for everything and your fridge were the only electrical appliance you had then it might pencil out, especially if you built your own insulated cold storage box to higher standards.
But for the same expense and hassle you could probably do it electrically even if you had to set up panels or wind/Hydro to do it.
Also would be interesting to know how the efficiencies would compare between an RV style absorption fridge burning propane and using propane to make power to run a compressor either via a generator or fueling an IC engine and belt driven compressor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519654
For the power bank, lead batteries are not recommended since they aren't meant to be repeatedly charged and discharged in such deep cycles. Lead batteries are better for emergencies, as a backup power source. Lithium batteries (there are many kinds) can be placed in parallel in order to form a power bank, but they are much more expensive and fragile. You would need to either constantly monitor the voltage and current of the batteries in order to avoid overcharging, drawing too much current, etc. There are systems you can buy for this, but they are expensive. Solar creates DC, but you would need a device to regulate the amount of charge it delivers to the battery to avoid overcharging. The wind turbine and Sterling engine create AC, which has to be converted to DC with a rectifier in order to charge the batteries (again, device needed to protect battery from overcharging). When you're ready to use your stored power, you need a power inverter to convert DC to AC so you may use it in your home. As for the bicycle, many people have used alternators to generate electricity, but once again, it creates an irregular AC signal which has to be converted to DC and then fed into a voltage regulator that can stabilize the output voltage and charge the batteries.

posts.com:
I live off grid, I wouldn't say there's a single best choice for each, it depends on your personal situation and having redundant systems is superior. This is my setup for what its worth
>Power
12kw solar panels into 2x 5kw inverters into a 3kw battery inverter with 15kwh of batteries, built this way to generate as much useable power in winter, at a cost of wasted peak production in summer.
I'd like to upgrade the battery inverter and batteries at some point
petrol generator
I'd like to add wind to the mix, but am not sure what size I should get or how I should wire it into the rest of the system
>Water
rainwater
springwater
either source is pumped up to tanks above the house that provide pressure via gravity. I've only ever used the springwater during a bad drought. Glad it is there though.
>Heating
fireplace
woodfired oven
electric blankets
I live in Australia, the winters don't get cold enough to run the fireplace except for a few of the coldest days of the year, the woodfired oven is what we mostly use as it provides cooking and hot water as well as heating.
>Hot water
gets its own mention
I have 3 ways of getting hot water
water jacket on the wood-fired oven
instant gas system
excess solar feeds into a hot water tank, 8 months out of the year we generate enough solar for this
>Cooling
ceiling and pedestal fans
>Septic
Aerated wastewater treatment system
backup: shit in a hole/bucket

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2519243
I'll answer your 5, and then tell you the 2 most imporant considerations you're missing.

>Power
Solar. A properly sized solar system will power all your non-heat loads in winter, and in summer will give ample power for cooling.
You can go full /diy/ on this, you can buy everything brand new, or anything in between. If you use LiFePo4 batteries, the thing that will fail the soonest is the inverter-charger-controller. A system made with quality components can easily work for 20 years without problems, and longer if you buy some spares.
For backup power, a diesel generator. They will run off of all kinds of fuel, and are pretty easy to fix.

>Water
This greatly depends on your area. In my locale (Western PA), you could live off of catchment water alone. Other places will need a well or desalination method.
For storage, it's hard to beat a massive cistern in the ground. The water should be somewhat filtered before going in, and filtered again when coming out. You pump the water up into a tank in the attic to give you pressure. This pump can be powered by anything - solar, wind, a horse, you, etc.

>Heating
Wood/coal/straw/poo fired boiler heating a giant insulated hot water tank, which acts as heat storage. Traditional wood stove as a secondary/backup. Optional ground source heat pump can handle all your heating (and cooling) needs when there's enough solar power, allowing you to save your fuel for those very cold and dark days.

>Cooling
Proper location and passive construction will help with this. Building partly underground/into a hill will allow you to leverage the earth's constant temperature for a source of cool in the summer, and heat in the winter. No matter what you build, insulation is a must. Ground source heat pump is the best method of active cooling.

>Septic
Septic tank is ez, or you can treat it yourself by aerating the sewage in multiple stages. The resulting water will be clean enough to discharge direct.

cont. Part 1/2

Part 2/2

While OP's 5 things are important to our modern life, he's missing two critically important considerations:

>Location
>Food

Location will influence virtually everything else. Trying to live off grid in the middle of the desert will be radically different than living in the southeastern US, which will be different than living off grid in the north.
The ideal location will have ample water, minimal risk of disasters, arable land, and climate that's not outright hostile. It's also important to consider the people living nearby, because you will have to interact with them, and they will affect your life.

Food is of utmost importance. You could have the perfect setup to take care of OP's "Big Five", but if you don't have a way to grow food, you're going to be at the mercy of the economy. Grow energy rich foods like sweet potatoes, corn, etc, and raise chickens + goats for meat, eggs, and milk.


I personally don't believe there will be any kind of "collapse" or "SHTF" in the way that doomers dream about, as that would essentially require every country on earth to get carpet bombed by nukes. That said, I understand the desire to live free of a system which seems to actively discourage any kind of self-sufficency.

>>2522445
>i don't understand having to pump septic tank
Over time, a septic tank will fill up with "non-digestible" material.... All the organic matter breaks down, with some of the resulting compounds being CO2 or methane etc that is volatile and will exit the system, or with water soluble compounds that will leach out through as effluent. But ultimately, some material will remain.

Eventually, you have to pump or dig this material out if you wish to continue using the system. On a reasonably sized system, you shouldn't need to pump it more than every decade or so.
There are estimates about the volume per person per year which will slowly fill the tank due to solid human waste alone, and other estimates which take toilet paper and other product usage into account as well.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524192
>what build plates do yall recommend
PEI coated spring steel on magnetic base. Smooth and textured handle most materials without needing adhesives or release agents, and those things are easy to apply and clean on a smooth sheet if needed.

>hat fiberglass circuit board material?
Also a good option (G10/garolite), though options for mounting it to a spring steel base are limited, and without that it can be prone to warping with high temp materials like the nylon it's best with unless you get a thick enough sheet to make it too stiff to flex parts off.

>and is PETG any good as "general purpose"?
More or less. It has decent mechanical properties at a decent price, and has good UV resistance and enough heat resistance to handle direct sunlight. It's rather stringy and droopy though, so it's not very suited to aesthetic models.

>how bad does it want to peel and warp?
Worse than PLA, not as bad as polycarbonate. On a (clean) textured PEI sheet it's not an issue for most prints, but large parts with warp/detachment-prone geometry may peel without measures like a brim. Smooth PEI is not recommended because it sticks too well without a release agent. An enclosure may help but it's generally not needed or even useful. One thing about PETG is that the raw material is highly transparent, and so there are interesting transparent options. I've made things that look like cobalt glass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524636
>Does a bed leveler fix this?
Yes.

>How do those work?
The print head moves a probe to multiple spots around the bed and builds a map of the bed's distortion, which is used to distort the gcode to make it "flat" relative to the maybe-distorted bed. This is usually done before every print.

>Is there a way to see the readings from the leveler?
In principle yes, but not all setups are made to easily show that information.

>Are there ways to get the leveling data into the slicer to see the slicer adapt to the warped bed?
In principle yes, but so far as I know none do that since there's no point, as that route is far inferior to having the printer do it on the fly with the actual just-measured bed distortion.

It sounds like you've had some frustrating experiences with providing services through the internet. It can be tough to find reliable and fair clients, and it can be especially frustrating when you put in a lot of effort only to be compensated poorly.

One way to try to avoid these kinds of situations is to be more selective about the clients you choose to work with. You could consider setting clear boundaries and expectations upfront, such as requiring a minimum order size or charging a post fee as you mentioned. You could also try to get a better sense of a potential client's needs and expectations before agreeing to work with them, to ensure that the project is a good fit for both parties.

It's also important to remember that not every client or project is going to be a good fit, and it's okay to turn down work if it doesn't align with your goals or values. By being more selective and setting clear boundaries, you may be able to avoid some of the frustrating situations you've experienced in the past.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525190
Underextrusion can be variable depending on how fast the extruder tries to push plastic through. See how the gaps close up at the corners where the print head is moving slower? It looks like your parameters are such that the faster (long straight or gently-curving) moves are fast enough to push the extruder into territory where it underextrudes significantly. One possible solution is to reduce the maximum speed to avoid excessively fast flow rates. Another is to increase nozzle temp to increase the hot end's melt capacity beyond the point where it underextrudes.

Yes, extra well. I don't really recommend that resin though, as I've bought it in the past and it has shrinking and delaminating problems. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525236
>8.3 mm3/s
This could easily be around the max depending on material, nozzle, hot end, and temperature. If that's PLA and a .4mm nozzle, 218C isn't particularly hot, and while a V6 with a powerful direct drive can force it faster, that doesn't have a whole lot of headroom at that temp.

>what do you suggest I do to fix this? It's a structural print
If it's PLA, temp to ~240 and use a .8mm or so CHT nozzle. That on its own should massively increase the melt capacity. I dial in high flow settings with a vase mode print that I measure to find underextrusion at different parameters.

>>2525238
Note that those flow rates are a combination of extrusion width and the nominal speed for that type of feature, not the actual speed which the print head will attain (which includes acceleration and deceleration). Note that the straight / large-curve high-flow areas there match the underextruded areas in the previous image, and the problem goes away in lower-flow areas and corners (where the print head slows down).

M201 X500.00 Y500.00 Z100.00 E5000.00 ;Setup machine max acceleration
M203 X500.00 Y500.00 Z10.00 E50.00 ;Setup machine max feedrate
M204 P500.00 R1000.00 T500.00 ;Setup Print/Retract/Travel acceleration
M205 X8.00 Y8.00 Z0.40 E5.00 ;Setup Jerk
M220 S100 ;Reset Feedrate

G28 ;Home
G29 ;Probe

G1 Z2.0 F3000 ;Move Z Axis up

G1 X10.4 Y200.0 Z0.28 F5000.0 ;Move to side a little

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525678
The clear advantage over glass is that you can release prints with just a flex (or most of the time just cooling down too). And you don't need scraping anymore.
As for the glue stick gluestick is usually meant to decrease adhesion to manageable levels, although I havent had much problem without it (using PLA, PLA+, ABS, ABS+ , PETG). But apparently with some people PETG (and TPU) bind too well to the surface and make it very hard to remove. Then again, I have heard the same with PETG+Glass and I never had issues with that either.
It has good adhesion to nearly any material.

Also, the textured PEI doesnt require any additional gluestick, at least with PLA, PLA+ and PETG it works fine. I am going to try ABS+ tonight and see how well it works.

By the way, I am not aware of many people using plain springsteel, as generally its coated in PEI, any info on it?

>>2525749
I use Nylon a lot for my job/research, but its such a pain with FDM that I just order/outsource it with SLS printing.
Although it has some good properties (PA12 Nylon is the best material to print compliant mechanisms/flexures out of, hence I use it) it has ome other problems people don't often talk about:
Printed parts get extremely brittle over time from what I think is water exposure.
Nylon has extremely bad creep problems.

Especially the second one severely limits the use cases for mechanisms/constructions which are normally under load/preloaded.
The Nylon will deform under the load, increasing the stress until it breaks. The rate of creep is about twice as bad as most other plastics iirc, but worse is that it doesn't 'flatten out' and keeps creeping until failure.

tl;dr Use Nylon only for mechanisms and structures which aren't preloaded or under constant (significant) load.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525724
>It's HTPLA. Does that mean
Its meaning is like "PLA+". There isn't a standardized set of terminology, and manufacturers can call things what they want, more or less. Presumably the manufacturer in this case has changed the recipe a bit from standard PLA in a way that references high temperatures somehow, but you'd have to check the actual spool / supplementary materials to see what it's actually supposed to do.

>it'll crystallize further and get more transparent?
PLA (and plastics in general) become less transparent when they crystallize. Annealing PLA changes the amorphous as-printed plastic to a crystallized form that is much more heat resistant. "HTPLA" is generally not more heat resistant than regular PLA after annealing, but there's supposed to be something in it that makes that process easier somehow. The kind I use (Volcano PLA) anneals with virtually no distortion, which is what usually causes trouble with the endeavor. Burying a part in sand is intended to reduce distortion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've got a 130 year old two story house that's badly in need of a lot of things. I have a rough idea of the most sensible sequence in which things need to be done. A new water heater is on the list, but it's waiting on an electrical overhaul, which in turn is waiting on other things. Unfortunately, the regulator on my water heater seems to have begun to leak gas into my kitchen, and I don't think I want to spend $200 (the price of a new regulator) to repair a unit I plan on throwing away as soon as possible. I'm therefore faced with installing a water heater before my electrical system is ready for it.

I want to replace my 40 gallon gas water heater with a tankless electric one. I want it to be electric precisely so that it can't malfunction and leak explosive gas into my kitchen, and tankless because there's not a good location for a water heater in my house, which was built without closets. It's currently in the corner of the kitchen, where it's a major eyesore. Another reason to go with an electric heater is that I'd like to perform as much of the installation as possible myself and to be able to service it myself moving forward, and I am much more comfortable working with electricity than with gas.

A 27 kW water heater calls for 3 x 40 A breakers and pulls up to 112.5 A. A have a 200 A main panel with room for those breakers. Unfortunately, the typical load on that panel is pretty high thanks to my reliance on resistive heating (electric radiators - no ductwork yet) and to the fact that it supplies not only a large-ish house but also a large-ish workshop. I'm probably using 80 - 100 amps for heat, and I can see myself using 25 A for other stuff if I'm working in the shop. If, say, two other people are using hot water at the same time, I can see that 200 amp capacity being exceeded.

The worst that can happen is that I flip my main breaker, right? Should I just fix my gas one?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525534
>Should I just fix my gas one?
If I were you, I would just get on facebook marketplace, craigslist or whatever the locally relevant apps/sites are in your area and buy a cheap used gas water heater. In my area at least, you can usually snag one for around 100$. This would be a fast, cheap, and functional move-- even if it's only a temporary fix and you wind up doing a different solution later.

Electric tankless units are kind of wacky because of their huge power requirements. Swapping to a 400A main panel plus the cost of the thicc cable run for the tankless is going to wind up being expensive as fuck, and you'd never break even on the energy savings.
The only reason that tankless make sense is for certain use cases where you actually need to use hundreds of gallons of hot water in an hour. (or niche applications where you need the especially hot 185f water they can provide for commercial service)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525534
First off, are you sure there's something wrong with the regulator? It could be as simple as a bad connection. Start with some soapy water to find where the leak is coming from.

Your worst case here is that you rip out your gas unit, the elec heater doesn't work without more power, and you have no hot water until your electrical overhaul is done. If that's an acceptable risk to you, by all means, save the $200. Personally I'd take the risk because I like cold showers.

Finally, I would crunch the numbers and figure out your energy costs. How much does the on-demand unit cost to run, and how long will it take to pay for itself. I suspect it won't, and you seem to be focusing on saving money here?

Anyway, good luck. And don't be afraid of gas. Just get a little sensor alarm

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"Slab jacking" is a thing, but I've never known anyone to diy it.
Basically drill holes in the existing slab & pump concrete slurry underneath, until you level out the pieces. When it cures the soil underneath will be stabilized. It's very common for sidewalks, driveways, but you can fix concrete floors with it too. It's not cheap, but it's less than tearing out the entire floor & repouring.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G__DpXRsJXE

Here are some of the concerns I have:
- There seem to be 2 living rooms, one close to the kitchen where the TV is, and one left from the entrance with no TV and large book in the middle. Do spaces like that end up being used at all? Or would it just be an unusable area I heat for no reason?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525923
Open spaces are neat until you realize whatever mess you make in one of the areas affects the whole floor with varying degrees.

For example cooking. Frequent use of the frying pan will leave fatty residue everywhere even with a fume hood. Simply look at the top of your kitchen shelves after a year.

Also heating such spaces is a bitch. Walls or dividers would hinder airflow and capture heat in areas which this way is next to impossible without selective floor heating.

Getting alone time is also harder. Getting some distance to do something in silence and solitute, be it taxes, reading or something or just taking a nap on the couch is also hampered.

Connecting some spaces is convenient. Like the living room and a seperate eating area. However inviting the problems of wholly seperate rooms with their unique use cases and problems is imo ill advised.

>>2525245
>heated everywhere using floor heating, but keeping some rooms colder, for example living room, bedrooms and bathrooms at 24 C, and halls at 18 C. Does it make a huge difference?
This is a bad example because if you have decent insulation in the buildings outer envelope, then it's unlikely that you would see such a large variation of 6C difference between the various rooms and the hall.

You're going to have to be a lot more specific about the particulars of the design and the outside climate in order to try to get even a rough estimate of energy usage differences.

It's a lot easier to simply look at the energy usage difference between an entire house kept at 18c vs 24c and then realize that in your example the energy usage would fall somewhere in between these two numbers.

Spoiler alert: it's not going to be a large amount of energy saved IF you're not in an arctic climate and if the building envelope has excellent insulation. It's negligible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525274
You can estimate the heating need of the building by considering the building envelope area and the thermal conductivity (watts per square meter per degree kelvin) of the various building assemblies.

When you have a well insulated structure, you can wind up with a "diminishing returns" situation with continuing to add more and more insulation, because the heat losses will be absolutely dominated by losses through the windows and doors and through the ventilation air.

If you had a house with no doors or windows and no ventilation that was a 250m2 building with 4m high walls made from good 200mm thermobrick and 100mm styro board, along with a decent floor and attic insulation -- it could be kept 24C inside when it's 0C outside with only a few hundred watts worth of heat pump usage. The doors, windows, and makeup air would dominate a calculation like this.

I invite you to search about doing heat loss calculation for houses... in the USA we have the ANSI "Manual J" which describes the sizing of HVAC equipment based on the insulance and conductance of various building assemblies along with taking into account the ventilation requirements and heat produced from appliances etc. I'm sure there is something similar in the EU standards.

You can run some quick numbers for a house with your specifications and you will find that keeping the bedrooms and hallways at different temps as well as having high ceilings will make little difference in your ultimate heating bills as long as the building is well insulated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525320
>Get a nice thick oak door or something.
A nice 2" thick solid oak door has an R-value of about 1.5. A decent wall assembly is going to be R20+.
It's likely that a single door like this will lose more heat than the entire rest of the wall that it's set into.
